I would now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today wi
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. We remind you that these results are preliminary as we have not yet filed our 10-K.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes interest expense, restructuring and other charges included in the other expense line of our P&L. 
Restructuring charges tend to be fairly discreet in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. These numbers are reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release.
We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we've provided today, along with our 2009 Form 10-K and 2010 Form 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations.
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; and Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO. I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and hello, everyone. 2010 was a year of solid improvement. We delivered on all key measures for the full year and we made progress on our longer-term goals as well. We saw strong top line growth in our two largest segments, Pressure-sensit
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and hello, everyone. 2010 was a year of solid improvement. We delivered on all key measures for the full year and we made progress on our longer-term goals as well. 
We saw strong top line growth in our two largest segments, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services, which more than offset the decline in Office and Consumer Products. Both segments benefited from our strong position in emerging markets and an increased focus on marketing to end customers.
We expanded margins year-over-year. However, margins came under pressure in the second half of the year as raw material inflation outpaced price increases. While we narrowed the gap in the fourth quarter, we didn't close it. Our number one priority right now is to close that gap in the face of additional inflation by raising prices as well as accelerating material substitutions and taking productivity actions.
The highlight of the year was our improved financial strength. We generated $379 million of free cash flow which we used to reduce debt by nearly $300 million, exceeding our targeted net debt-to-EBITDA ratio. The rating agencies have improved their outlooks. We also contributed more than required to our pension plans, $78 million, and continued to invest in growth and in infrastructure.
Putting ourselves in a position to return more cash to shareholders was the key objective for 2010, and we achieved our goal. As we announced this morning, we increased our quarterly dividend by 25%, and we have a new authorization per share repurchases.
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased 3 million shares, offsetting dilution, and the board has authorized us to repurchase an additional 5 million shares. 
Now turning to the businesses. Pressure-sensitive Materials had low double-digit organic sales growth with strength in all regions. Operating margin was up year-over-year but down sequentially as inflation continue to pressure margin. As I've said, we ended the year with a gap between price and raw material costs, and we intend to close not only with price increases but with material substitutions and productivity.
During the year, we saw the benefits of our investments in end-user marketing to specific segments such as food, beverage, pharma and durables. We built a large pipeline of projects with end users to accelerate the conversion to pressure-sensitive from alternative forms of package decoration. And as a result, we're capturing new business.
Our Roll Materials business announced two significant innovations last year. One is the new system for labeling curved surfaces, and the other is a new product platform that uses dramatically thinner liner materials that are lower cost and more sustainable. And our Graphics and Reflective Products business launched a new line of films for digital printers that are best in class. 
I'm very pleased with the progress Retail Information Services made last year. RIS delivered much stronger sales growth through dramatic improvements in service and quality. Margin improved as we saw the benefit of increased volumes on lower fixed costs.
We're starting to deliver on our value proposition to retailers and brand owners who responded very positively to the products and solutions we launched last year. RIS has further to go, but it's starting to realize its potential for sales growth and margin expansion. And although small, an important part of the long-term RIS success story is RFID. Shipments in the year of RFID inlays for apparel nearly doubled over last year, and we expect continued strong growth in 2011.
Office and Consumer Products year turned out as expected, given the continued weakness in white collar employment and the impact of new competition. We executed a solid defense of our labels business. We also invested in innovation and created a pipeline of new products that should be visible at retail in the back half of 2011. 
In summary, we exceeded our targets for the year. Our employees did a great job executing on our strategies by serving customers well. And I'm really pleased to be in a position to deliver increased cash to shareholders.
For 2011, our business priorities are as follows. First, close the price inflation gap. We have a long history of recovering inflation-related margin loss over the cycle and fully expect to follow that pattern again, while further improve RIS' market position as well as sales and margin. We will continue to drive the conversion to Pressure-sensitive Materials in key segments with innovative new solutions. And we'll continue to invest in the turnaround of Office Products and start generating sales out of this new product pipeline.
We expect that capital expense will be higher in 2011, about $175 million, but still significantly below our depreciation rate and our run rate prior to the recession. Our priorities for capital are disciplined investments organic growth especially in emerging markets and ramping up the IT infrastructure investments that we deferred during the recession. 
Finally, we remain focused on generating strong free cash flow to support these investments and to return more cash to shareholders. Now I'll turn it over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through the Slide 9. Sales in the fourth quarter were up organically about 9%. As Dean mentioned, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services again delivered solid growth in all regions and
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through the Slide 9. Sales in the fourth quarter were up organically about 9%. As Dean mentioned, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services again delivered solid growth in all regions and more than offset the decline in Office Products. 
Our operating margin increased in the fourth quarter, as expected, to 5.9% as the benefit of higher volume more than offset the impact of the price inflation gap, reduced margin in office products and increased investments in growth and infrastructure. While raw materials came in the fourth quarter pretty much as expected, inflationary pressure did pick up in December, and that pressure has carried into this year. 
We previously said that we anticipated narrowing the price inflation gap early in 2011. The continued rise in raw material cost, however, has further delayed the timing of when we expect to close the price inflation gap. This inflation affects all of our segments. The majority of it though is in Pressure-sensitive Materials and the other specialty converting businesses. I'll provide more color on that in a moment.
Before getting into the segments, I want to point out that the discrete tax planning event that we flagged in October came in at $0.42. This benefit will be realized through lower cash tax payments over the coming years. And without this benefit, our effective tax rate for the year would have been 23%.
Turning to Slide 10. Our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment again delivered strong organic revenue growth of 11%, driven primarily by volume gains in all regions of our Raw Materials business. While PSM's operating margin in the quarter was up 30 basis points year-over-year, margin versus the third quarter was down half a point due to the raw material inflation. 
The inflation that we're currently facing is primarily due to the rising cost of adhesive components which is being driven by higher commodity prices as well as supplier capacity constraints. We are managing our global vendor network to help mitigate this inflation, seeking sensitive materials reduce costs, driving further productivity and working to offset the rest with price increases. 
In fact, we're planning another round of price increases for this spring. And this is on top of those that we just implemented. We're confident that the margin will expand from its current level in Pressure-sensitive as the combination of pricing and other protective measures offset rising input costs. 
Retail Information Services finished the year with organic sales growth of 11% in the quarter. This business, which was hit hard during the recession due to retail inventory destocking, is making great progress on the top and bottom lines. We are clearly building momentum in the marketplace. And with a strong operating leverage in this business, expect continued margin expansion as we grow. We've demonstrated this over the past year as the operating margin here has expanded four full points in the quarter and nearly six points for the full year.
Looking at Office Products, the decline in sales in the fourth quarter reflected weak end-market demand and increased competition in the labels category. As expected, Office Products' operating margins declined in the quarter due to increased consumer promotions, investments in growth and lower volume. We've previously discussed the competitive situation here, and our strategy is to reverse the trajectory of the business. So the margins will reman under pressure and actually further erode in the near term as we feel the full effect of actions taken last year to defend our position in the labels category as well as investments in innovation.
Our other specialty converting businesses again had solid sales growth in Q4, and margins have improved as a result of the benefit of increased volume and productivity gains. Now while margins improved, the overall margin for this collection of businesses remained in the red in Q4 due primarily to that price inflation gap.
Moving on to the outlook for 2011. On Slide 13, we've highlighted the key factors that we think will contribute to our P&L and cash flow in 2011. Slide 14 has our EPS and free cash flow guidance. 
We estimate organic revenue growth of approximately 6%, reflecting our large and growing presence in emerging markets and benefits from our investments in growth, as well as some lift in pricing actions. Based on the estimated sales and other assumptions including the listed factors, we expect adjusted EPS of $3 to $3.30 and free cash flow of $325 million to $350 million.  
This guidance assumes $140 million to $150 million of inflation. As I said earlier, we are working to mitigate this inflation by leveraging our global vendor network, driving further productivity and planning additional price increases. That said, the uncertainty about the timing of when we close the price inflation gap is one of the key factors driving the range in our EPS guidance. 
Now let me highlight some of the other key considerations reflecting our guidance. As mentioned earlier, we expect the operating margin in the Office and Consumer Products business to further erode in 2011 before rebounding. We anticipate Q1 EPS as a percent of full year earnings to be on the lower side of historical norms, that is close to the 15% of full year earnings. This is due to tougher comps in office products and the timing of the price inflation gap in Pressure-sensitive, as well as the fact that it is the seasonally lowest quarter for RIS. We expect that our ongoing pension expenses will be less than last year, reflecting changes made to our U.S. retirement plan. And we expect CapEx to be approximately $175 million.
This is well below D&A and below prerecession levels. Our disciplined approach to capital management and our Lean Sigma productivity effort should enable us to continue to invest below D&A for the near future.
Overall, we are confident about our position and prospects and with good reason. We're expecting another year of solid revenue growth in 2011, driven by momentum in emerging markets and Retail Information Services. We expect to close the price inflation gap in Pressure-sensitive and CPSM's margin expense. RIS will continue to build momentum in both its top and bottom lines. On a constant-tax basis, we expect 8% to 20% earnings growth in 2011 and free cash flow remains strong. 
Given the strength of our balance sheet, we shifted the focus of free cash flow from debt reduction to returning more cash to shareholders. We've reduced net debt to less than 2x EBITDA, and both rating agencies recently indicated improved sentiment of our financial strength. It's great to be back in the position of raising the dividend and buying back stock, great indicators of our confidence in our financial strength and growth prospects.  
I'll now turn it over to questions.

componenttext: We won't really see that until -- we had a good fourth quarter, so some of the spring season orders are already in there. But really, the real strength in the business, we'll start to see that in the March, April, May time frame. That tends to be the really heavy season for RIS.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, our competitors are raising prices and there's certainly intention to. I think the one difference between our input costs and some of our competitors' is that a lot of the intensity last year came on the monomer and adhesive side. So we inten
componenttext: Yes. I mean, our competitors are raising prices and there's certainly intention to. I think the one difference between our input costs and some of our competitors' is that a lot of the intensity last year came on the monomer and adhesive side. So we intended to see that inflation maybe a quarter before our competitors did, which -- they would get buffered because they buy their adhesives on the outside. But certainly, it's now showing up in their margins. So I think we'll see an increased incentive for competitors to increase prices.

componenttext: Sure. So at a high level, it's basically three major components to the $175 million of capital. componenttext: And is there anything noteworthy on the IT infrastructure side in terms of what you're doing there? is that kind of an ongoing maintenance-type number or is there something specific that you're ramping?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there are a couple of things. Recall that for Retail Information Services, we had announced after the acquisition of Paxar that we needed to invest in IT systems to allow us to integrate a lot of disparate system. During the recession, we said, "No,
componenttext: Well, there are a couple of things. Recall that for Retail Information Services, we had announced after the acquisition of Paxar that we needed to invest in IT systems to allow us to integrate a lot of disparate system. During the recession, we said, "No, we'll wait." And so now is the time to make that investments and now that businesses got a really good traction. Also, there is some systems that are getting at the end of life that we need to replace. So I think we're getting back to a "more normalized level" of IT spending.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: To clarify on that, is that capital that's going to get return or is that really more of required expenditure?
componenttext: To clarify on that, is that capital that's going to get return or is that really more of required expenditure?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the RIS expenditures have a nice returns. So I'm excited about that. Some of the other ones, like replacing things like financial systems, don't necessarily have a return. It's just maintenance capital.
componenttext: Well, the RIS expenditures have a nice returns. So I'm excited about that. Some of the other ones, like replacing things like financial systems, don't necessarily have a return. It's just maintenance capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you think about your key customers within Pressure-sensitive Materials -- and really here I'm thinking about the label converters, how have they progressed in the last 12 months? What kind of shape were they in to ultimately pass along input cost infla
componenttext: As you think about your key customers within Pressure-sensitive Materials -- and really here I'm thinking about the label converters, how have they progressed in the last 12 months? What kind of shape were they in to ultimately pass along input cost inflation from you and elsewhere? And are you seeing any kinds of interesting developments or innovations in label converting that maybe help accelerate growth or will it be in a more or less running around what the volume trends are within the CPG sector?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question, George. I think last year, the label converters were getting fatigued by the price increases. And I believe it's because many of them, during 2010, were kind of locked in to fixed-price contracts for the year with a number of th
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question, George. I think last year, the label converters were getting fatigued by the price increases. And I believe it's because many of them, during 2010, were kind of locked in to fixed-price contracts for the year with a number of their customers across many sectors. And we've done, I think, the best we could in educating their marketplaces. That's not really a good idea in this environment. So my sense in talking to a lot of label converters is that they're reluctant now to sign up for full year price guarantees because we can't give them any kind of protection on raw material inflation. So I think 2011 will be a bit of a different game for most label converters. For my perspective, the innovation in the marketplace is really being driven by our end user marketing efforts in terms of coming up with new solutions like the Curvy container product and a thinner liner material innovation which allows us to explore other types of applications that typically have not been pressure sensitive. Well, we've got a number of innovations that we'll be launching later this year at Labelexpo. So yes, I think 2010 was a tough year, but I think people now in the industry realize that this inflation is going to be with us for a while. And I anticipate label converters, actually, having raw material price through contracts with their customers best as they can.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi, Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi, Robert W. Baird.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dean, as we look back over the last few years, '08 was clearly a year of market dislocation, '09 perhaps is best characterized as cost cutting and maybe a modest recovery, '10 was a year of volume improvement but higher inflation. How would you qualify '1
componenttext: Dean, as we look back over the last few years, '08 was clearly a year of market dislocation, '09 perhaps is best characterized as cost cutting and maybe a modest recovery, '10 was a year of volume improvement but higher inflation. How would you qualify '11 as you see it right now? Is this the year of margin catch up?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, it depends. Here's the way I look at this. so the last time we went through major inflation, and there's always a gap for us to catch up. Our trough is actually higher than it was before. So over the cycle, I think we've been definitely making
componenttext: Yes, again, it depends. Here's the way I look at this. so the last time we went through major inflation, and there's always a gap for us to catch up. Our trough is actually higher than it was before. So over the cycle, I think we've been definitely making progress. And what we're doing up for this year is, I think volumes will be good. That's our sense, especially in emerging markets where we have a good position. We expect inflation to continue, and we're going to be aggressive about catching up with that. But also, we're going to get aggressive with suppliers on material substitution side. We've been working over the last 18 months very hard to renew suppliers in the marketplaces, especially in emerging markets. And some of that's going to bear fruit this year. So in that respect, we're able to take a little more control over our own destiny.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next version is a follow-up question from John E, Roberts, Buckingham Research Group.
componenttext: Our next version is a follow-up question from John E, Roberts, Buckingham Research Group.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the importance of apparel to the RIS business, is the record-high fiber cost that apparel makers are facing causing them to time their volumes or do anything with their volumes that might affect labels that go on apparel?
componenttext: Given the importance of apparel to the RIS business, is the record-high fiber cost that apparel makers are facing causing them to time their volumes or do anything with their volumes that might affect labels that go on apparel?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Not really. I think the apparel guys will change some of the fabrics they use. So they'll use more polyester-cotton blends than just pure cotton because cotton is at record high. They still have to get products into the stores for the normal season so I d
componenttext: Not really. I think the apparel guys will change some of the fabrics they use. So they'll use more polyester-cotton blends than just pure cotton because cotton is at record high. They still have to get products into the stores for the normal season so I don't anticipate any issues there. And so I don't sense that. If anything, I think, there's still a tremendous opportunity for us to gain share in this business. Because apparel companies want to enhance their brands, they're looking for more sustainable products. There's a lot of solutions that we can offer retailers and brand owners that help them improve their gross profit margins. I think we're in a good position.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I may have asked this before, but are there placements of RIS machines that act as a leading indicator of your business or something like that you can talk about, that the ticketing machine installations are up year-over-year or something like that?
componenttext: I may have asked this before, but are there placements of RIS machines that act as a leading indicator of your business or something like that you can talk about, that the ticketing machine installations are up year-over-year or something like that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're already everywhere we need to be. So there's no really leading indicator there for us. We kind of get a lead indicator on how retailers are feeling about the upcoming season because they order, obviously, months in advance of when the product h
componenttext: Yes, we're already everywhere we need to be. So there's no really leading indicator there for us. We kind of get a lead indicator on how retailers are feeling about the upcoming season because they order, obviously, months in advance of when the product has to be in the stores. And again, we'll see that. I actually felt we had a pretty good fourth quarter. I mean, for me, retailers were optimistic about consumers wanting to spend, and they've spent on apparel. And we'll see in a few months about how folks feel about the fall season when we get the orders coming in and again the March, April time frame.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So my understanding, Dean, is that acrylic prices keep moving up in first quarter. If acrylics haven't moved up in the first quarter, would you have caught up to the raw material cost inflation that you felt in the fourth quarter in the first quarter?
componenttext: So my understanding, Dean, is that acrylic prices keep moving up in first quarter. If acrylics haven't moved up in the first quarter, would you have caught up to the raw material cost inflation that you felt in the fourth quarter in the first quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Within the first quarter we would catch up towards the middle of the first quarter, we would be expecting to catch up. If we did not have this latest round of inflation, we just would not be planning the current price increase for spring.
componenttext: Yes. Within the first quarter we would catch up towards the middle of the first quarter, we would be expecting to catch up. If we did not have this latest round of inflation, we just would not be planning the current price increase for spring.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in your commentary on office products, you said that you would still be under a little bit of pressure. Were there any unusually good items in the fourth quarter? That is, was the volume a little bit better than you expected? And for next year, it sou
componenttext: And in your commentary on office products, you said that you would still be under a little bit of pressure. Were there any unusually good items in the fourth quarter? That is, was the volume a little bit better than you expected? And for next year, it sounds like you're expecting down operating profits for the year. Is that correct?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first on the fourth quarter, we did see more volume coming through. And basically, that was some customers did some prebuying to I think help their year end. They improved their rebate levels a little bit. We see it's varying from year-to-year but
componenttext: Yes. So first on the fourth quarter, we did see more volume coming through. And basically, that was some customers did some prebuying to I think help their year end. They improved their rebate levels a little bit. We see it's varying from year-to-year but it's little more than we expected in Q4. Here's my expectation for 2011 for office products, and that is, we'll be investing in demand creation and new product development, plus were going to feel the full year impact of the losses that we had in the label category in 2010. But I expect sales to level up, because we'll start to see product placements for a lot of our new product categories. And that would really start with the back-to-school period and in the fall. So that's when we'll really see the benefits of the investments we're making there.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: How much business have you lost or how much business did you lose in 2010?
componenttext: How much business have you lost or how much business did you lose in 2010?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: It wasn't that much. In the label category, remember, which is about a $200 million category. I think, run rate basis, we lost six or seven share points in total. So we actually only lost placement at one retailer. And we didn't lose it in the catalog and
componenttext: It wasn't that much. In the label category, remember, which is about a $200 million category. I think, run rate basis, we lost six or seven share points in total. So we actually only lost placement at one retailer. And we didn't lose it in the catalog and we still have the high volume SKUs at that retailer. So from my perspective, the team did a really good job of defending our market share position. Of course, it costs us some money, but it is absolutely the right thing to do.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Putting all of that commentary together, to Jeff's question, the fact that you get the leveling off and the leverage in the second half of the year when you get back to back-to-school season and earlier when we were talking about Pressure-sensitive Materi
componenttext: Putting all of that commentary together, to Jeff's question, the fact that you get the leveling off and the leverage in the second half of the year when you get back to back-to-school season and earlier when we were talking about Pressure-sensitive Materials pricing pass-through and that you'll more or less catch up at some point in the second quarter. Given with what you know of the world right now with input costs, does it seem logical then that in terms of the quarterly progressions that the first half of the year, the company is running perhaps flat to down versus last year given the comparisons and where you really get the earnings growth within the second half of 2011?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So overall, let me just put this in a frame that's centered around of what we're expecting of office products. We're investing in this business to reverse the trajectory of the business both on the top and bottom lines. We're expecting 2011 to further ero
componenttext: So overall, let me just put this in a frame that's centered around of what we're expecting of office products. We're investing in this business to reverse the trajectory of the business both on the top and bottom lines. We're expecting 2011 to further erode both top and bottom lines but the pace of erosion to slowdown on the top line. And then in the middle of the year, particularly with the peak season and back to school, we'll be able to launch a number of new products, and we'll be able to start to see the sales come through from that. It'll still be relatively small on how you measure from a financial perspective in 2011. It's really going to provide a great base for moving into 2012. So you think about how things play out for the year. Overall, you should be thinking of office products still showing some erosion on top line but is slowing down in the pace. And margins, too, as I said earlier, further erode as well, full year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question was more of an aggregate Avery Dennison. In other words if I take the trend and comparisons in office and the price cost pass-through battle year you got underway within Pressure-sensitive Materials, it sounds like, at least from our vantage p
componenttext: My question was more of an aggregate Avery Dennison. In other words if I take the trend and comparisons in office and the price cost pass-through battle year you got underway within Pressure-sensitive Materials, it sounds like, at least from our vantage point, first half of 2011 for Avery Dennison in aggregate, earnings are probably more like to be flat to down. Obviously, you've given us guidance for that year and that more than 100% of the growth should come in the second half. Would that be a fair assessment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The growth in a company-wide level, yes. You should expect more of that to be back half. Remember also, when you think about this, is RIS, their second quarter is seasonally the highest. And so that significant amount of the earnings usually about a third
componenttext: The growth in a company-wide level, yes. You should expect more of that to be back half. Remember also, when you think about this, is RIS, their second quarter is seasonally the highest. And so that significant amount of the earnings usually about a third of our full year earnings come in the second quarter all other things being equal because of RIS' seasonality. But aside from that point, you're right. Second half is when you would expect more of the profit to come through.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011

componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of John E. Roberts, Buckingham Research.

componenttext: The 100% growth that you had in RFID Q4-over-Q4, was that broad based and/or did it include a major ramp by any U.S. retailer?

componenttext: Certainly, a big part of the growth was in apparel RFID tags. But we also had growth in other segments where we sell RFID inlays. So from that perspective, it was pretty broad based. And we did have a couple of customers in the U.S. ramp up their RFID programs.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks for joining the call today. And to sum up, we had a solid 2010 and we feel good about 2011. As I noted earlier, our priorities for the year are to close the price inflation gap and expand margins, provide sales growth with our investments in
componenttext: Well, thanks for joining the call today. And to sum up, we had a solid 2010 and we feel good about 2011. As I noted earlier, our priorities for the year are to close the price inflation gap and expand margins, provide sales growth with our investments in marketing and innovation and continue to generate strong free cash flow, enabling us to return more cash to shareholders. Thanks, everyone, for joining, and we look forward to speaking with you again.

componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Welcome to the Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the Fourth Quarter and Full Year Ended January 1, 2011. [Operator Instructions] To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21496533. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today wi
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. We remind you that these results are preliminary as we have not yet filed our 10-K.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes interest expense, restructuring and other charges included in the other expense line of our P&L. 
Restructuring charges tend to be fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. These numbers are reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release.
We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we've provided today, along with our 2009 Form 10-K and 2010 Form 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations.
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; and Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO. I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and hello, everyone. 2010 was a year of solid improvement. We delivered on all key measures for the full year and we made progress on our longer-term goals as well. We saw strong top line growth in our two largest segments, Pressure-sensit
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and hello, everyone. 2010 was a year of solid improvement. We delivered on all key measures for the full year and we made progress on our longer-term goals as well. 
We saw strong top line growth in our two largest segments, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services, which more than offset the decline in Office and Consumer Products. Both segments benefited from our strong position in emerging markets and an increased focus on marketing to end customers.
We expanded margins year-over-year. However, margins came under pressure in the second half of the year as raw material inflation outpaced price increases. While we narrowed the gap in the fourth quarter, we didn't close it. Our number one priority right now is to close that gap in the face of additional inflation by raising prices as well as accelerating material substitutions and taking productivity actions.
The highlight of the year was our improved financial strength. We generated $379 million of free cash flow which we used to reduce debt by nearly $300 million, exceeding our targeted net debt-to-EBITDA ratio. The rating agencies have improved their outlooks. We also contributed more than required to our pension plans, $78 million, and continued to invest in growth and in infrastructure.
Putting ourselves in a position to return more cash to shareholders was the key objective for 2010, and we achieved our goal. As we announced this morning, we increased our quarterly dividend by 25%, and we have a new authorization for share repurchases.
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased 3 million shares, offsetting dilution, and the board has authorized us to repurchase an additional 5 million shares. 
Now turning to the businesses. Pressure-sensitive Materials had low double-digit organic sales growth with strength in all regions. Operating margin was up year-over-year but down sequentially as inflation continued to pressure margin. As I've said, we ended the year with a gap between price and raw material costs, and we intend to close not only with price increases but with material substitutions and productivity.
During the year, we saw the benefits of our investments in end-user marketing to specific segments such as food, beverage, pharma and durables. We built a large pipeline of projects with end users to accelerate the conversion to pressure-sensitive from alternative forms of package decoration. And as a result, we're capturing new business.
Our Roll Materials business announced two significant innovations last year. One is the new system for labeling curved surfaces, and the other is a new product platform that uses dramatically thinner liner materials that are lower cost and more sustainable. And our Graphics and Reflective Products business launched a new line of films for digital printers that are best in class. 
I'm very pleased with the progress Retail Information Services made last year. RIS delivered much stronger sales growth through dramatic improvements in service and quality. Margin improved as we saw the benefit of increased volumes on lower fixed costs.
We're starting to deliver on our value proposition to retailers and brand owners who responded very positively to the products and solutions we launched last year. RIS has further to go, but it's starting to realize its potential for sales growth and margin expansion. And although small, an important part of the long-term RIS success story is RFID. Shipments in the year of RFID inlays for apparel nearly doubled over last year, and we expect continued strong growth in 2011.
Office and Consumer Products year turned out as expected, given the continued weakness in white collar employment and the impact of new competition. We executed a solid defense of our labels business. We also invested in innovation and created a pipeline of new products that should be visible at retail in the back half of 2011. 
In summary, we exceeded our targets for the year. Our employees did a great job executing on our strategies by serving customers well. And I'm really pleased to be in a position to deliver increased cash to shareholders.
For 2011, our business priorities are as follows. First, close the price inflation gap. We have a long history of recovering inflation-related margin loss over the cycle and fully expect to follow that pattern again. We'll further improve RIS' market position as well as sales and margin. We will continue to drive the conversion to Pressure-sensitive Materials in key segments with innovative new solutions. And we'll continue to invest in the turnaround of Office Products and start generating sales out of this new product pipeline.
We expect that capital expense will be higher in 2011, about $175 million, but still significantly below our depreciation rate and our run rate prior to the recession. Our priorities for capital are disciplined investments for organic growth especially in emerging markets and ramping up the IT infrastructure investments that we deferred during the recession. 
Finally, we remain focused on generating strong free cash flow to support these investments and to return more cash to shareholders. Now I'll turn it over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through to Slide 9. Sales in the fourth quarter were up organically about 9%. As Dean mentioned, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services again delivered solid growth in all regions and m
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through to Slide 9. Sales in the fourth quarter were up organically about 9%. As Dean mentioned, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services again delivered solid growth in all regions and more than offset the decline in Office Products. 
Our operating margin increased in the fourth quarter, as expected, to 5.9% as the benefit of higher volume more than offset the impact of the price inflation gap, reduced margin in office products and increased investments in growth and infrastructure. While raw materials came in the fourth quarter pretty much as expected, inflationary pressure did pick up in December, and that pressure has carried into this year. 
We previously said that we anticipated narrowing the price inflation gap early in 2011. The continued rise in raw material cost, however, has further delayed the timing of when we expect to close the price inflation gap. This inflation affects all of our segments. The majority of it though is in Pressure-sensitive Materials and the other specialty converting businesses. I'll provide more color on that in a moment.
Before getting into the segments, I want to point out that the discrete tax planning event that we flagged in October came in at $0.42. This benefit will be realized through lower cash tax payments over the coming years. And without this benefit, our effective tax rate for the year would have been 23%.
Turning to Slide 10. Our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment again delivered strong organic revenue growth of 11%, driven primarily by volume gains in all regions of our Roll Materials business. While PSM's operating margin in the quarter was up 30 basis points year-over-year, margin versus the third quarter was down half a point due to the raw material inflation. 
The inflation that we're currently facing is primarily due to the rising cost of adhesive components which is being driven by higher commodity prices as well as supplier capacity constraints. We are managing our global vendor network to help mitigate this inflation, seeking substitute materials reduce costs, driving further productivity and working to offset the rest with price increases. 
In fact, we're planning another round of price increases for this spring. And this is on top of those that we just implemented. We're confident that the margin will expand from its current level in Pressure-sensitive as the combination of pricing and other protective measures offset rising input costs. 
Retail Information Services finished the year with organic sales growth of 11% in the quarter. This business, which was hit hard during the recession due to retail inventory destocking, is making great progress on the top and bottom lines. We are clearly building momentum in the marketplace and with a strong operating leverage in this business, expect continued margin expansion as we grow. We've demonstrated this over the past year as the operating margin here has expanded four full points in the quarter and nearly six points for the full year.
Looking at Office Products, the decline in sales in the fourth quarter reflected weak end-market demand and increased competition in the labels category. As expected, Office Products' operating margins declined in the quarter due to increased consumer promotions, investments in growth and lower volume. We've previously discussed the competitive situation here, and our strategies to reverse the trajectory of the business. So the margins will remain under pressure and actually further erode in the near term as we feel the full effect of actions taken last year to defend our position in the labels category as well as investments in innovation.
Our other specialty converting businesses again had solid sales growth in Q4, and margin has improved as a result of the benefit of increased volume and productivity gains. Now while margins improved, the overall margin for this collection of businesses remained in the red in Q4 due primarily to that price inflation gap.
Moving on to the outlook for 2011. On Slide 13, we've highlighted the key factors that we think will contribute to our P&L and cash flow in 2011. Slide 14 has our EPS and free cash flow guidance. 
We estimate organic revenue growth of approximately 6%, reflecting our large and growing presence in emerging markets and benefits from our investments in growth, as well as some lift in pricing actions. Based on the estimated sales and other assumptions including the listed factors, we expect adjusted EPS of $3 to $3.30 and free cash flow of $325 million to $350 million.  
This guidance assumes $140 million to $150 million of inflation. As I said earlier, we are working to mitigate this inflation by leveraging our global vendor network, driving further productivity and planning additional price increases. That said, the uncertainty about the timing of when we close the price inflation gap is one of the key factors driving the range in our EPS guidance. 
Now let me highlight some of the other key considerations reflecting our guidance. As mentioned earlier, we expect the operating margin in the Office and Consumer Products business to further erode in 2011 before rebounding. We anticipate Q1 EPS as a percent of full year earnings to be on the lower side of historical norms, that is closer to 15% of full year earnings. This is due to tougher comps in office products and the timing of the price inflation gap in Pressure-sensitive, as well as the fact that it is the seasonally lowest quarter for RIS. We expect that our ongoing pension expenses will be less than last year, reflecting changes made to our U.S. retirement plan. And we expect CapEx to be approximately $175 million.
This is well below D&A and below prerecession levels. Our disciplined approach to capital management and our Lean Sigma productivity effort should enable us to continue to invest below D&A for the near future.
Overall, we are confident about our position and prospects and with good reason. We're expecting another year of solid revenue growth in 2011, driven by momentum in emerging markets and Retail Information Services. We expect to close the price inflation gap in Pressure-sensitive and CPSM's margin expense. RIS will continue to build momentum in both its top and bottom lines. On a constant-tax basis, we expect 8% to 20% earnings growth in 2011 and free cash flow remains strong. 
Given the strength of our balance sheet, we've shifted the focus of free cash flow from debt reduction to returning more cash to shareholders. We've reduced net debt to less than 2x EBITDA, and both rating agencies recently indicated improved sentiment about our financial strength. It's great to be back in the position of raising the dividend and buying back stock, great indicators of our confidence in our financial strength and growth prospects.  
I'll now turn it over to questions.

componenttext: The question I have, and I realize it's difficult to pinpoint this because it all depends on when input costs stop increasing and at what rate this increased over this period. But when do you think, given your view of the world right now and the price increases that you have contemplated for 2011, that you'll actually catch up and narrow the price cost gap in PSM to zero?

componenttext: Well, George, you actually said it. It depends on how much inflation keeps going. That's the big wildcard. I'd say, our goal, assuming the inflation that we put into the guidance is to do that by the second quarter.

componenttext: It's basically, it's one of the key factors of the range of our guidance. So if all other things being equal, you could assume the higher end of the range assumes that's earlier in the year, early second quarter and the lower end of the guidance is that it is later than that.

componenttext: Yes, Ghansham. Recall that everything that was sold in the fourth quarter was already build by us in the second quarter and part of the third quarter. So we tend to be -- before the products are shipped is when we're doing the billing. So our expectations going forward -- it was  a pretty good apparel season. The inventory-to-sales ratio remains at historically low level. So I'm pretty optimistic about the 2011 for Retail Information Services.

componenttext: So just to clarify, so just given how strong the quarter was for your customers, is that translated into increased order flow for '11?

componenttext: We won't really see that until -- we had a good fourth quarter, so some of the spring season orders are already in there. But really, the real strength in the business, we'll start to see that in the March, April, May time frame. That tends to be the really heavy season for RIS.

componenttext: I don't think we want to comment on the actual pricing that we saw within the various segments for a specifically -- for a particular quarter or year. But overall, what we've been seeing is that inflation really started ramping up in Q2 and built in Q3 and Q4, and now we're seeing it build in Q1. And our pricing has been about a quarter lag from that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the pressure-sensitive area, you put through some pretty sizable price increases. Did you see what you would view as an appropriate competitive response in the industry?
componenttext: In the pressure-sensitive area, you put through some pretty sizable price increases. Did you see what you would view as an appropriate competitive response in the industry?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, our competitors are raising prices and there's certainly incentive to. I think the one difference between our input costs and some of our competitors' is that a lot of the intensity last year came on the monomer and adhesive side. So we inten
componenttext: Yes. I mean, our competitors are raising prices and there's certainly incentive to. I think the one difference between our input costs and some of our competitors' is that a lot of the intensity last year came on the monomer and adhesive side. So we intended to see that inflation maybe a quarter before our competitors did, which -- they would get buffered because they buy their adhesives on the outside. But certainly, it's now showing up in their margins. So I think we'll see an increased incentive for competitors to increase prices.

componenttext: Well, we really don't comment on the timing of share repurchases. But overall, our intent is to return more cash to shareholders. Obviously, we've done that with the dividend. And our intent is to devote more of our free cash flow to buying back shares as well.

componenttext: Yes. That business is a mix of different businesses. Our tapes business is the largest entity in there. And they've had a bit of a tough year in terms of passing along raw material inflation. But then we have a number of new start-up businesses in that sector as well. So our RFID business is in there. We've got a couple of other small converting businesses in there as well. So it's pretty small and I do expect it to be better in 2011.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could help us to break down the $175 million of capital. Is there much in there for IS, information spending? And then the growth capital, how much of that is emerging markets? And can you share how you're thinking about which markets hol
componenttext: I was hoping you could help us to break down the $175 million of capital. Is there much in there for IS, information spending? And then the growth capital, how much of that is emerging markets? And can you share how you're thinking about which markets hold the most promise?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. So at a high level, there's basically three major components to the $175 million of capital. About a third of it is from investments in growth, principally in emerging markets, the vast majority of that is for emerging market investments. Another th
componenttext: Sure. So at a high level, there's basically three major components to the $175 million of capital. About a third of it is from investments in growth, principally in emerging markets, the vast majority of that is for emerging market investments. Another third of it is for productivity-related investments and maintenance capital within mature markets. And the last third is for IT infrastructure.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So in emerging market CapEx, we're adding a significant amount of capacity in India for our Pressure-sensitive Materials business. We're also adding investments in capacity in Asia for Retail Information Services, as well as raw materials business, so Chi
componenttext: So in emerging market CapEx, we're adding a significant amount of capacity in India for our Pressure-sensitive Materials business. We're also adding investments in capacity in Asia for Retail Information Services, as well as raw materials business, so China and other places in South Asia.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And is there anything noteworthy on the IT infrastructure side in terms of what you're doing there? Is that kind of an ongoing maintenance-type number or is there something specific that you're ramping?
componenttext: And is there anything noteworthy on the IT infrastructure side in terms of what you're doing there? Is that kind of an ongoing maintenance-type number or is there something specific that you're ramping?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, there are a couple of things. Recall that for Retail Information Services, we had announced after the acquisition of Paxar that we needed to invest in IT systems to allow us to integrate a lot of disparate systems. During the recession, we said, "No
componenttext: Well, there are a couple of things. Recall that for Retail Information Services, we had announced after the acquisition of Paxar that we needed to invest in IT systems to allow us to integrate a lot of disparate systems. During the recession, we said, "No, we'll wait." And so now is the time to make that investment and now that business has got a really good traction. Also, there are systems that are getting at the end of life that we need to replace. So I think we're getting back to a "more normalized level" of IT spending.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: To clarify on that, is that capital that's going to get return or is that really more of required expenditure?
componenttext: To clarify on that, is that capital that's going to get return or is that really more of required expenditure?

componenttextpreview: Well, the RIS expenditures have a nice return. So I'm excited about that. Some of the other ones, like replacing things like financial systems, don't necessarily have a return. It's just maintenance capital.
componenttext: Well, the RIS expenditures have a nice return. So I'm excited about that. Some of the other ones, like replacing things like financial systems, don't necessarily have a return. It's just maintenance capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you think about your key customers within Pressure-sensitive Materials -- and really here I'm thinking about the label converters, how have they progressed in the last 12 months? What kind of shape are they in to ultimately pass along input cost inflat
componenttext: As you think about your key customers within Pressure-sensitive Materials -- and really here I'm thinking about the label converters, how have they progressed in the last 12 months? What kind of shape are they in to ultimately pass along input cost inflation from you and elsewhere? And are you seeing any kinds of interesting developments or innovations in label converting that maybe help accelerate growth or will it be in a more or less running around what the volume trends are within the CPG sector?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question, George. I think last year, the label converters were getting fatigued by the price increases. And I believe it's because many of them, during 2010, were kind of locked in to fixed-price contracts for the year with a number of th
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question, George. I think last year, the label converters were getting fatigued by the price increases. And I believe it's because many of them, during 2010, were kind of locked in to fixed-price contracts for the year with a number of their customers across many sectors. And we've done, I think, the best job we could in educating that marketplace to say that's not really a good idea in this environment. So my sense in talking to a lot of label converters is that they're reluctant now to sign up for full year price guarantees because we can't give them any kind of protection on raw material inflation. So I think 2011 will be a bit of a different game for most label converters. From my perspective, the innovation in the marketplace is really being driven by our end use marketing efforts in terms of coming up with new solutions like the Curvy container product and a thinner liner material innovation which allows us to explore other types of applications that typically have not been pressure sensitive. Well, we've got a number of innovations that we'll be launching later this year at Labelexpo. So yes, I think 2010 was a tough year, but I think people now in the industry realize that this inflation is going to be with us for a while. And I anticipate label converters, actually, having raw material price-through contracts with their customers best as they can.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi, Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi, Robert W. Baird.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dean, as we look back over the last few years, '08 was clearly a year of market dislocation, '09 perhaps is best characterized as cost cutting and maybe a modest recovery, '10 was a year of volume improvement but higher inflation. How would you qualify '1
componenttext: Dean, as we look back over the last few years, '08 was clearly a year of market dislocation, '09 perhaps is best characterized as cost cutting and maybe a modest recovery, '10 was a year of volume improvement but higher inflation. How would you qualify '11 as you see it right now? Is this the year of margin catch up?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, it depends. Here's the way I look at this. So the last time we went through major inflation, and there's always a gap for us to catch up. Our trough is actually higher than it was before. So over the cycle, I think we've been definitely making
componenttext: Yes, again, it depends. Here's the way I look at this. So the last time we went through major inflation, and there's always a gap for us to catch up. Our trough is actually higher than it was before. So over the cycle, I think we've been definitely making progress. And what we're gearing up for this year is, I think volumes will be good. That's our sense, especially in emerging markets where we have a good position. We expect inflation to continue, and we're going to be aggressive about catching up with that. But also, we're going to get aggressive with suppliers on the material substitution side. We've been working over the last 18 months very hard to bring new suppliers in the marketplaces, especially in emerging markets. And some of that's going to bear fruit this year. So in that respect, we're able to take a little more control of our own destiny.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next version is a follow-up question from John E. Roberts, Buckingham Research Group.
componenttext: Our next version is a follow-up question from John E. Roberts, Buckingham Research Group.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given the importance of apparel to the RIS business, is the record-high fiber cost that apparel makers are facing causing them to time their volumes or do anything with their volumes that might affect labels that go on apparel?
componenttext: Given the importance of apparel to the RIS business, is the record-high fiber cost that apparel makers are facing causing them to time their volumes or do anything with their volumes that might affect labels that go on apparel?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Not really. I think the apparel guys will change some of the fabrics they use. So they'll use more polyester-cotton blends than just pure cotton because cotton is at a record high. They still have to get product into the stores for the normal season so I
componenttext: Not really. I think the apparel guys will change some of the fabrics they use. So they'll use more polyester-cotton blends than just pure cotton because cotton is at a record high. They still have to get product into the stores for the normal season so I don't anticipate any issues there. And so I don't sense that. If anything, I think, there's still a tremendous opportunity for us to gain share in this business. Because apparel companies want to enhance their brands, they're looking for more sustainable products. There's a lot of solutions that we can offer retailers and brand owners that help them improve their gross profit margins. I think we're in a good position.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I may have asked this before, but are there placements of RIS machines that act as a leading indicator of your business or something like that you can talk about, that the ticketing machine installations are up year-over-year or something like that?
componenttext: I may have asked this before, but are there placements of RIS machines that act as a leading indicator of your business or something like that you can talk about, that the ticketing machine installations are up year-over-year or something like that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're already everywhere we need to be. So there's no really leading indicator there. For us, we kind of get a lead indicator on how retailers are feeling about the upcoming season because they order, obviously, months in advance of when the product
componenttext: Yes, we're already everywhere we need to be. So there's no really leading indicator there. For us, we kind of get a lead indicator on how retailers are feeling about the upcoming season because they order, obviously, months in advance of when the product has to be in the stores. And again, we'll see that. I actually felt we had a pretty good fourth quarter. I mean, for me, retailers were optimistic about consumers wanting to spend, and they've spent on apparel. And we'll see in a few months about how folks feel about the fall season when we get the orders coming in and again the March, April time frame.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So my understanding, Dean, is that acrylic prices keep moving up in the first quarter. If acrylics haven't moved up in the first quarter, would you have caught up to the raw material cost inflation that you felt in the fourth quarter in the first quarter?
componenttext: So my understanding, Dean, is that acrylic prices keep moving up in the first quarter. If acrylics haven't moved up in the first quarter, would you have caught up to the raw material cost inflation that you felt in the fourth quarter in the first quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Within the first quarter we would catch up towards the middle of the first quarter, we would be expecting to catch up. If we did not have this latest round of inflation, we just would not be planning the current price increase for spring.
componenttext: Yes. Within the first quarter we would catch up towards the middle of the first quarter, we would be expecting to catch up. If we did not have this latest round of inflation, we just would not be planning the current price increase for spring.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in your commentary on office products, you said that you would still be under a little bit of pressure. Were there any unusually good items in the fourth quarter? That is, was the volume a little bit better than you expected? And for next year, it sou
componenttext: And in your commentary on office products, you said that you would still be under a little bit of pressure. Were there any unusually good items in the fourth quarter? That is, was the volume a little bit better than you expected? And for next year, it sounds like you're expecting down operating profits for the year. Is that correct?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first on the fourth quarter, we did see more volume coming through. And basically, that was some customers did some prebuying to I think help their year end. They improved their rebate levels a little bit. We see this varying from year-to-year but
componenttext: Yes. So first on the fourth quarter, we did see more volume coming through. And basically, that was some customers did some prebuying to I think help their year end. They improved their rebate levels a little bit. We see this varying from year-to-year but it's little more than we expected in Q4. Here's my expectation for 2011 for office products. And that is, we'll be investing in demand creation and new product development, plus were going to feel the full year impact of the losses that we had in the label category in 2010. But I expect sales to level up, because we'll start to see product placement for a lot of our new product categories. And that would really start with the back-to-school period and in the Fall. So that's when we'll really see the benefits of the investments we're making there.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: How much business have you lost or how much business did you lose in 2010?
componenttext: How much business have you lost or how much business did you lose in 2010?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: It wasn't that much. In the label category, remember, which is about a $200 million category. I think, run rate basis, we lost six or seven share points in total. So we actually only lost placement at one retailer. And we didn't lose it in the catalog and
componenttext: It wasn't that much. In the label category, remember, which is about a $200 million category. I think, run rate basis, we lost six or seven share points in total. So we actually only lost placement at one retailer. And we didn't lose it in the catalog and we still have the high volume SKUs at that retailer. So from my perspective, the team did a really good job of defending our market share position. Of course, it costs us some money, but it was absolutely the right thing to do.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from George Staphos, Bank of America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Putting all of that commentary together, to Jeff's question, the fact that you get the leveling off and the leverage in the second half of the year when you get back to back-to-school season and earlier when we were talking about Pressure-sensitive Materi
componenttext: Putting all of that commentary together, to Jeff's question, the fact that you get the leveling off and the leverage in the second half of the year when you get back to back-to-school season and earlier when we were talking about Pressure-sensitive Materials pricing pass-through and that you'll more or less catch up at some point in the second quarter. Given with what you know of the world right now with input costs, does it seem logical then that in terms of the quarterly progressions that the first half of the year, the company is running perhaps flat to down versus last year given the comparisons and where you really get the earnings growth within the second half of 2011?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So overall, let me just put this in a frame that's exactly around of what we're expecting of office products. We're investing in this business to reverse the trajectory of the business both on the top and bottom lines. We're expecting 2011 to further erod
componenttext: So overall, let me just put this in a frame that's exactly around of what we're expecting of office products. We're investing in this business to reverse the trajectory of the business both on the top and bottom lines. We're expecting 2011 to further erode both top and bottom lines but the pace of erosion to slowdown on the top line. And then in the middle of the year, particularly with the peak season and back to school, we'll be able to launch a number of new products, and we'll be able to start to see the sales come through from that. It'll still be relatively small on how you measure from a financial perspective in 2011. It's really going to provide a great base for moving into 2012. So when you think about how things play out for the year overall you should be thinking of office products still showing some erosion on top line but is slowing down in the pace. And margins, too, as I said earlier, further erode as well, full year.

componenttext: The growth on a company-wide level, yes. You should expect more of that to be back half. And so that significant amount of the earnings usually about a third of our full year earnings come in the second quarter -- all other things being equal because of RIS' seasonality. But aside from that point, you're right. Second half is when you would expect more of the profit to come through.

componenttext: Well, thanks for joining the call today. And to sum up, we had a solid 2010 and we feel good about 2011. As I noted earlier, our priorities for the year are to close the price inflation gap and expand margins,  drive sales growth with our investments in marketing and innovation and continue to generate strong free cash flow, enabling us to return more cash to shareholders. Thanks, everyone, for joining, and we look forward to speaking with you again.
