headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's been some recent announcements within the paper industry that what's been traditionally a put in writing capacity as demand has been declining, maybe moving into the production instead of special grade like base stock, police liners and the like.
componenttext: There's been some recent announcements within the paper industry that what's been traditionally a put in writing capacity as demand has been declining, maybe moving into the production instead of special grade like base stock, police liners and the like. Do you think that, that might be able to have a beneficial effect at some point in the next 12 months in terms of the inflation that you're seeing right now? Whatever thoughts you have around that? Then taking it from a different tech, can you just update us on what your capacity expansion plans are for this year and if there any coders that you know of from some of your larger competitors that are going up this year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. George, I'm hopeful that more people get into this business. I don't think it will impact us much this year. We've spent a lot of time over the last few years developing new sources of supply in emerging markets in the film area and in the paper are
componenttext: Sure. George, I'm hopeful that more people get into this business. I don't think it will impact us much this year. We've spent a lot of time over the last few years developing new sources of supply in emerging markets in the film area and in the paper area. And that's actually helped us, especially in times of somewhat tighter supply. But typically, unfortunately, when someone announces they're going to get into the specialty paper business it's capital investment, it takes time and then they've got to figure out how to actually makes the grades that we buy. So I'm not too hopeful for 2011, and maybe in 2012 will -- that will help us. In terms of our capacity expansion, the number one expansion that we're executing right now is in India. In fact, I was there over the last couple of weeks and that projects is right on track to come online in the back half of the year. Still, very solid growth in South Asia. And in other parts of the world, frankly, we're able to -- China, we made a big investment a couple of years ago, so we're still in pretty good shape there. And in Europe, in North America, we're handling the volume increases simply with the ongoing productivity. I would expect though with emerging market growth continuing at the rate that it's growing that, that will be the next area for somewhere in Asia or even South America, we're  going to need to make some more investments in capacity going on. I've not heard of major investments in capacity by competitors. There might be some small ones if there are, I'm not just aware of it.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dean, on the emerging market capacity, when that does come in, if it does come, is that a -- do you have enough capacity in these markets to get through 2012 or could we, in fact, see the next coder coming in 2012? And I would imagine with the coder, you
componenttext: Dean, on the emerging market capacity, when that does come in, if it does come, is that a -- do you have enough capacity in these markets to get through 2012 or could we, in fact, see the next coder coming in 2012? And I would imagine with the coder, you have some additional splitting in distribution capacity that you have to put in place. Obviously that's not going to be as capital intensive but nonetheless, it would seem that, that would also have to go hand in glove?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, that's a normal part of the process. Now normally we don't put in all the finishing capacity at the same time as you do coding because the coder's capacity generally last for two or three years in those markets. So we do split that out a lit
componenttext: Sure. I mean, that's a normal part of the process. Now normally we don't put in all the finishing capacity at the same time as you do coding because the coder's capacity generally last for two or three years in those markets. So we do split that out a little bit. My guess is -- and we haven't done our planning yet. We normally have our planning meetings in June on capital is that -- we'll likely be doing something in emerging markets in 2012. I just don't know exactly where yet, we're still trying to figure that out.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, George, when we've look at -- talked about the capital expenditure for this year, we said about 1/3 of that would be to growth, most of that investment's in the emerging markets. So there's the coder capacity that's also adding some more splitters, m
componenttext: And, George, when we've look at -- talked about the capital expenditure for this year, we said about 1/3 of that would be to growth, most of that investment's in the emerging markets. So there's the coder capacity that's also adding some more splitters, more investments within the RBIS space and so forth. So overall, that is getting a disproportionate share of the capital going forward.

componenttext: Okay. Thanks for the reminder on that, Mitch. The last question and then I'll turn it over. headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Well, just to sum up, we made progress in the first quarter against our three main priorities. We made progress on inflation, it's accelerating again and we're taking further actions to close the cost in price gap. Retail Branding and Informati
componenttext: Thank you. Well, just to sum up, we made progress in the first quarter against our three main priorities. We made progress on inflation, it's accelerating again and we're taking further actions to close the cost in price gap. Retail Branding and Information Solutions continues to build momentum, improving both sales and margin. And Office and Consumer Products is on track for improvement later this year. And as Mitch said, we're maintaining our full year earnings guidance and free cash flow target and remain committed to returning cash to shareholders. Thanks, everyone, for joining, and we look forward to speaking with you again.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Welcome to Avery Dennison Earnings Conference Call for the Second Quarter Ended July 2, 2011. This call is being recorded, and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific tim
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Welcome to Avery Dennison Earnings Conference Call for the Second Quarter Ended July 2, 2011. This call is being recorded, and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today through midnight Pacific time, July 29. To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21496535. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier along with the slide presentation titled Second Quarter 2011 Financial Review and Analyst. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and p
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier along with the slide presentation titled Second Quarter 2011 Financial Review and Analyst. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. We remind you that these unaudited results are preliminary as we've not yet filed our 10-Q.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin which includes interest expense, restructuring charges and other items included in the other expense line of our P&L. These items tend to fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on non-GAAP operating margins, which reflects pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to 85 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release.
We also reminder that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The safe harbor statement included in the documents that we provided today, along with our 2010 Form 10-K and 2011 Form 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations.
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; and Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. I want to start to say that I recognize the news that we gave you last week both unexpected and unpleasant. Organic growth x currency was down about 2% for the second quarter, compared to the 6.5% growth we saw in the first quarter. We exper
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. I want to start to say that I recognize the news that we gave you last week both unexpected and unpleasant. Organic growth x currency was down about 2% for the second quarter, compared to the 6.5% growth we saw in the first quarter. We experienced unexpected slowdown in all geographies and as well most of our businesses with the exception of our Office and Consumer Products business. 
Starting with Retail Branding and Information Solutions, sales decreased 6% on an abrupt decline in unit volumes across all customer groups and geographies, which pressured profits in this high variable margin business. A major factor in the order decline was the dramatic run-up in material and labor cost for apparel, which impacted retailers in 2 ways. First, very cautious about ordering garments with higher unit costs with correspondingly higher prices, especially in environment of uncertain consumer demand. Cotton prices and other material input peaked and then dropped rapidly in the quarter. This should costs unit cost for apparel to drop later this year, but because of that, our customers delayed or canceled orders to make sure they did not end up with large inventories of higher cost goods. Combined, these dynamics have the most impact on apparel, destined for the mass-market channel in the U.S. With unit volumes down significantly due to the magnitude of price increases on lower-priced garments, as well as a lack of consumer buying power and lower income levels.
While we expected a somewhat softer season this year due to the anticipated higher costs, we do not expect a rapid reduction in cotton and 
Other input prices. We expect the softness to continue until later this year and that's when retailers placed their orders for the 2012 season.
Turning to Pressure-sensitive Materials, it seems clear that overall economic activity slowed during the second quarter. We serve a wide range of end markets and Pressure-sensitive Materials, including food, durable goods and health and personal care. We also sell thousands of labor converters all over the world. And that makes it difficult to link our sales to end consumer sales. However, historically, this business has been a leading indicator for economic activity.
Labeling and Packaging Materials saw unit volume decline in every region, including emerging markets. Net sales on an organic basis were flat over last year because pricing actions offset the volume decline. This represents a big change from the first quarter when net sales grew almost 10%. It appears that like apparel, retailers and brands, consumer packaged goods companies are gaining cautious about consumer spending in the second half and are managing inventories tightly.
Label and Packaging Materials has led the industry on price increases that cover inflation and we made progress on narrowing the price inflation gap that developed in the second half of last year. As you know, we've been pushing prices up aggressively as raw material cost have escalated. As volumes softened in June, pricing became more challenging as competitors try to hang onto volumes and this happened especially in Europe. Now, at this point, we don't have any shared data from any of our markets, but we believe we may have lost a bit of share in the quarter as we prioritized getting our prices up. Now it's normal for us to lose a bit of share on the margin as we raise prices. So I'm confident that most of the volume losses related to lower market demand.
Now if there is a silver lining to this market softness, it's that we don't see inflation accelerating as it has for the last 5 quarters. I'm pleased that we've recovered most of the margin loss caused by inflation. It is likely we'll have to raise prices though in certain geographies and product lines to offset some of the remaining gap.
It's tough to predict how the rest of the year will play out. We have limited forward visibility in this business since we shipped out 80% of our orders in a 2-day window. We don't know yet if the lower activity level represents a shorts slowdown or a beginning of a more protractive trend. Our Other pressure sensitive business, Graphics and Reflective solutions had a good quarter, led by strong sales of new film products. 
Office and Consumer Products volumes sales and margin declined year-over-year as expected. We're  on track to launch new products in the second half, which combined with the Back-to-School season, will help Office and Consumer Products improved sales trends and meet its full year margin targets.
Given the trends in the quarter, we're assuming that a continuation of the market slowdown through year end is a real possibility and our updated guidance reflects that. We built in some very modest improvement in volumes, but also uncertainty about when in the second half it might occur. 
We're cutting expenses, setting our belts and reducing capital expenditures by $25 million, as well as evaluating additional opportunities to improve productivity. Our goal is to reduce expenses without sacrificing investment for the future.
Finally, although we do reduce guidance for free cash flow for the year, we remain focus on generating substantial free cash flow in the second half. We're committed to maintaining our strong balance sheet and returning more cash to shareholders. 
And now Mitch will take you through the details of the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through to Slide 9. Sales in the second quarter were up as reported by 3% but down about 2% organically. As Dean discussed, volume was the driver of the organic sales decline, particularly in our Pressure-se
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through to Slide 9. Sales in the second quarter were up as reported by 3% but down about 2% organically. As Dean discussed, volume was the driver of the organic sales decline, particularly in our Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Branding and Information Solutions segment. Volumes for the company were down approximately 5%, dropping up dramatically in June, historically the largest month in the quarter. The volume declines of course impacted our second quarter consolidated operating margin. Our operating margin of 8.2% was down 80 basis points from last year as the negative impact of lower volume was partially offset by a reduction in employee related costs, including lower expense for incentive compensation.
We've talked a lot about rising raw material cost over the last few quarters and they remain high. We've made great progress in offsetting inflation by implementing the productivity initiatives and price increases that we were talking about during our past few earnings report. 
As for marketing general and administrative expense, it declined versus last year due to lower employee related costs. Last quarter, we talked about stepping up growth in IT infrastructure related investments. We're still making investments in our most promising and potential initiatives will be reduced cost across the rest of the company, both structural changes and general belt-tightening.
Before getting into the segment, I want to point out that our year-to-date adjusted tax rate increase from 23% to 29%, largely reflecting an increased portion of our profit now expected to be in higher tax rate jurisdiction. 
I also want to comment on our year-to-date free cash flow, which included a net outflow in the second quarter very atypical for us. This net out flow is largely due to a combination of lower operating results and additional $25 million pension payments and changes in working capital. 
Now the changes -- the working capital changes primarily relates to the timing of cash payments for inventory. While we reduced inventories in the second quarter from the relatively high levels in Q1, the benefits of free cash flow will occur in the third quarter. These working capital changes and pension payments while negative for the quarter in the first half are not expected to impact the full year.
Now I'm sure you have noticed that our fee cash flow was out up sync with earnings in the quarter. This is largely because of reduction in our expectations for employee costs in 2011 are noncash this year and will not benefit free cash flow until the first quarter of next year.
Turning to Slide 10. Our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment delivered roughly flat organic sales growth, driven by declines in volume, largely offset by pricing. PSM volumes reflected year-over-year decline and all of label and packaging materials regions and the most categories. Volume in Graphics and Reflective solutions was up in the quarter. Dean said that a violence in the second quarter won't repeat them here. PSM's operating margin quarter was down 20 basis points year-over-year reflecting the decline in volumes and lower employee related costs. Sequentially, margin benefited from our narrowing of the price inflation gap.
Retail Branding and Information Solutions turned a 6% decline in organic sales in the second quarter, traditionally this segment, largest quarter of the year. The lower sales were due to lower unit volumes reflecting the softness in the market of our apparel 
units that Dean discussed earlier. 
With a decline in volumes, the relatively high operated have at this business work against us this quarter. More than you can see, the 140 basis point drop due to our lower employee related costs. Dean covered Office and Consumer products, which came in as expected. The second quarter is seasonally higher quarter for this business relative to Q1 as it includes part of the Back-to-School season, which concludes in Q3. We continue to expect margins for this business to be in the upper single-digit for the full year. And our Other Specialty Converting business delivered flat sales growth in the quarter with margins up 90 basis points from last year.
Moving on to the outlook for 2011. On Slide 13, we summarized the key factors that we expect to contribute to our P&L and cash flow in 2011. Slide 14 has our EPS and free cash flow guidance. I'll highlight just a few key assumptions that have changed from what we discussed last quarter. 
We now estimate organic sales growth in 2011 of approximately 1.5% to 3.5%, a big difference from the 7% assumption we made last quarter. Our current uncertainly about the market causes us to provide a pretty wide range for the top line in the second half.
We've increased our restructuring actions since last quarter and have accordingly increased our expectations of the cost to implement these actions. annualized savings associated with 2011 restructuring actions are expected to total approximately $40 million, at about 1/3 of the benefit to be realized this year. We continue to evaluate further opportunities to reduce cost, potentially including additional restructuring actions. And we've reduced our estimate for capital expenditures for the year by $25 million. 
Based on estimated sales and other assumptions including the listed factors, we now expect adjusted earnings for share in 2011 of $2.45 to $2.75. And free cash flow of $250 million to $275 million.
Notwithstanding the recent slowdown, we are confident our public is in a prospect our businesses up marketed which is it would be a competitive advantages and even with our guidance for free cash flow in 2011, we will maintain our financial strength, achieving our targeted debt level again later this year, and then increasing our return of cash to shareholders. 
Now I would be happy to take your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was curious, Dean, perhaps if you could help us breakdown of 5% organic volume declined into attributable factors, maybe you can help us rule some out. Do you think there was any demand in the first quarter for strength of the second quarter, do you thi
componenttext: I was curious, Dean, perhaps if you could help us breakdown of 5% organic volume declined into attributable factors, maybe you can help us rule some out. Do you think there was any demand in the first quarter for strength of the second quarter, do you think there is demand in the second part that is perhaps being shifted to the first quarter? And I think you did mention some competitive behavior was at this business as 100 or 200 basis points, anymore color you can offer on kind of the variances or the factors, that would be really helpful.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, peter. So I'd say there might have been a very small amount of shifting and I can't really quantify it because most of the evidence we have is anecdotal at this point. So in Retail Branding and Information Services, the first -- some of the first qu
componenttext: Sure, peter. So I'd say there might have been a very small amount of shifting and I can't really quantify it because most of the evidence we have is anecdotal at this point. So in Retail Branding and Information Services, the first -- some of the first quarter sales, I think were stronger than we had anticipated in the quarter because frankly people were just trying to get ahead of some of the unit costs that were coming in. And people at that point expected input cost to keep going up at the time so there were kind of buying early in the inflationary environment. That, of course, shifted pretty dramatically in the second quarter once cotton prices started to collapse. We may have had the a little bit of pre-buying in the Pressure-sensitive Materials, it would have been very small as a percentage of the total, so not really meaningful. And as part of the share position, we did see, in Europe, typically June is a pretty strong month for the Labeling and Packaging Materials business there. Because people are doing a lot of work before the summer holidays, the Food business tends to be very strong at that point of view and we just didn't see a search that we normally saw and some competitors , I think,  in a weakening environment, just couldn't offered to delay some price increases. The problem is we don't have that any market share data and we wont have it for a few weeks. I wish I could be more precise on that, but we just can't, at this point.

componenttext: Okay, and if understanding all that happen, would it be logical that if cotton were to bottom and turn to the other direction, that could bring buyers off to sidelines?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's actually you've seen some articles about this lately in the trade press, but also in places like the Wall Street Journal. So cotton prices are already down. The problem is not that cotton has not yet been turned into a gray goods, whic
componenttext: Well, I think, it's actually you've seen some articles about this lately in the trade press, but also in places like the Wall Street Journal. So cotton prices are already down. The problem is not that cotton has not yet been turned into a gray goods, which can be put into yarn and fabrics. And that really won't happen until later this year. So most companies are anticipating lower cotton cost and unit costs from a material perspective for 2012. They wont start ordering those products from us until very late in the third and in the fourth quarter, that's when we really start to see our fourth quarter surge in that business. So, yes -- I do see that, and I think there was actually an article in the Wall Street Journal about some people try and keep their prices up by just adding units to to their packs as a way of getting to the person am I getting unit volumes, which would be okay for us, by the way, that would be a good trend.

componenttext: So the primary reason for the change in the tax rate is related to the graphic income mix. So we now have when we lowered our income projections for the year, it was the were disproportionately in low tax rate jurisdictions, so that's what you call the increase in the tax rate. The discrete events was we commented there that was just about 20% or so of the change. So very small component of the overall change on the tax rate was around planning matter that we're looking out for later in the year that were not going to the but given the current environment. So primarily geographic mix and u asked about going forward, it depends on if you talk for the near-term, it really depends on what the geographic mix is going to and really what kind of environment we're in. But I'd say, it's still mid to perhaps a high 20% range.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've got a little bit of a gap left and we still have some price increases plan for going forward. But they're very either product line or geography specific. So relatively minor. I think this is the first quarter now over the last 5 quarters where we ha
componenttext: We've got a little bit of a gap left and we still have some price increases plan for going forward. But they're very either product line or geography specific. So relatively minor. I think this is the first quarter now over the last 5 quarters where we have announced additional inflation expectations over and above what we've had. So the environment we're in is more flattened out. And again, there's a couple of areas where we need to execute price increases to filling that gap.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then as best you can tell in the Pressure-sensitive area, I mean it sounds like there has been some increased at a competitive pressure. Have you seen your, I guess your major competitor or competitors raise price yet? Or it is it just a functio
componenttext: Okay, and then as best you can tell in the Pressure-sensitive area, I mean it sounds like there has been some increased at a competitive pressure. Have you seen your, I guess your major competitor or competitors raise price yet? Or it is it just a function that they were delayed or are they just not actively going that way or they are actually pushing their share?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've had everyone of our competitors has felt the same inflation pressure that we felt. And so, what we've seen is competitors following and raising prices in their markets. We just haven't heard an announcement earlier -- I'm sorry, late last we
componenttext: I think we've had everyone of our competitors has felt the same inflation pressure that we felt. And so, what we've seen is competitors following and raising prices in their markets. We just haven't heard an announcement earlier -- I'm sorry, late last week where one of our competitors in Europe has announced price increases again for certain geographies. So I still think that the competitors in this industry want to make money and they know they've got prices up in a time of rising raw material costs. I think that was a little sloppy in June in Europe, specifically, when the volumes shortfalls, we had a marketable volumes shortfall, both sometimes on the margins comp, some competitors feel that they're better off kind of but that volume in the short-term rather than raise prices. So we've seen this before. I do want to point out though that sequentially, we improved margins again in this sector. I mean that was a priority for us to fill that gap. And all that we've talking about the last 4 quarters has been inflation. Unfortunately, now we're talking about volume. So I think we've done a reasonable job of executing. And the team has done good job of executing, getting prices up in our key markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then one last question, just in terms of your customer base, I know I guess in certain areas that you've seen a lot of inflation and then when prices rollover, you saw de-stocking around that do you customers typically de-stocking try to play th
componenttext: Okay, and then one last question, just in terms of your customer base, I know I guess in certain areas that you've seen a lot of inflation and then when prices rollover, you saw de-stocking around that do you customers typically de-stocking try to play that pricing gamers or is that something that we really don't see like in the pressure sensitive area?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: For labels, printers and converters it's tough for them to do because they are in the custom business. I don't know we do with our customers are going to order. They don't hold a lot of finished goods inventory and most of these customers are relatively s
componenttext: For labels, printers and converters it's tough for them to do because they are in the custom business. I don't know we do with our customers are going to order. They don't hold a lot of finished goods inventory and most of these customers are relatively small. So and they don't have a lot of space so it's really tough for them to stock up either on a lot of our product for both the reductions. So we don't really see that kind of behavior. You see it again on the fringe.

componenttext: Can your apparel customers wait to see back-to-school sales before deciding what to do for the holiday season?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. They're always looking forward. They're already planning the 2012 season. And in their mix, we'll go things like what will apparel cost look like on a go forward basis, what's the consumer appetite for spending and certainly the back-to-school appar
componenttext: Sure. They're always looking forward. They're already planning the 2012 season. And in their mix, we'll go things like what will apparel cost look like on a go forward basis, what's the consumer appetite for spending and certainly the back-to-school apparel season for them will be an indicator of how confident the consumer will be and how much discounting they have to do during that specific season. So it's one of the inputs they look at to judge what the open numbers will be for 2012.

We adjust them each quarter based on our forecast for the year. And so in Q2, it was -- we do not accrue as much the normal amount for Q2. We also reduced some of the accruals that we've made in Q1.
We reversed them Q2.

componenttext: I don't anticipate that. This is, again, and the real question is how protracted will this market slowdown be. Could be just a pause. We had a bit of this in the fourth quarter when things slowdown and then things picked up very robustly in the first quarter. And so what I see is some relative choppiness out there. And so I am not anticipating any dramatic financial issues for our customers.

componenttextpreview: First question, I have is regarding reduction of your CapEx guidance by the $25 million, is this going to be a timing issue where that $25 million reduction gets added into 2012 or do you probably permanently scaled-back any of your growth or IT infrastru
componenttext: First question, I have is regarding reduction of your CapEx guidance by the $25 million, is this going to be a timing issue where that $25 million reduction gets added into 2012 or do you probably permanently scaled-back any of your growth or IT infrastructure spending?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it is a delay up for projects that we have planned. We won't automatically add it back to next year's capital expense budget. We haven't even really done our planning yet for 2012 and we look at 2012 in terms of what we expect our markets to look li
componenttext: Well, it is a delay up for projects that we have planned. We won't automatically add it back to next year's capital expense budget. We haven't even really done our planning yet for 2012 and we look at 2012 in terms of what we expect our markets to look like, what our free cash flows will be and will prioritize around that. So this is being slower it makes sense to soften up a little bit on the CapEx.

componenttext: No, I'm starting to feel that vendor 90. Yes. The last time -- I did go back -- we did go back and review a lot of the trends over the last couple of years. And so with that being said, I just -- that still doesn't really tell me what's going to happen on go forward basis. And it's something we're going to watch very closely over the next few quarters.

componenttext: On restructuring, George, it is part of our D&A. We're not doing a massive acceleration of the restructuring we're doing. I think that our Lean Six Sigma teams around the company doing really a good job of finding lots of productivity. And frankly, we did some restructuring in the end part of the quarter and early part of this quarter. At the corporate level. That's really has not much to do with the economy, the current economic situation, but had more to do with eliminating some functions and activities that would traditionally done at the corporate office that we believe our business units can more than easily handle it on their own. So working differently, eliminating complexity, et cetera, et cetera, those types of things. So we went ahead and did that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the second quarter ended July 2, 2011. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific Ti
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the second quarter ended July 2, 2011. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific Time today through midnight Pacific time, July 29. To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21496535. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier along with the slide presentation titled Second Quarter 2011 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier along with the slide presentation titled Second Quarter 2011 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. We remind you that these unaudited results are preliminary as we've not yet filed our 10-Q.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes interest expense, restructuring charges and other items included in the other expense line of our P&L. These items tend to be fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on non-GAAP operating margin, which reflects pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release.
We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we provided today, along with our 2010 Form 10-K and 2011 Form 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations.
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; and Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. I want to start to say that I recognize the news we gave you last week was both unexpected and unpleasant. Organic growth ex-currency was down about 2% for the second quarter compared to the 6.5% growth we saw in the first quarter. We experi
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. I want to start to say that I recognize the news we gave you last week was both unexpected and unpleasant. Organic growth ex-currency was down about 2% for the second quarter compared to the 6.5% growth we saw in the first quarter. We experienced unexpected slowdown in all geographies, and as well most of our businesses, with the exception of our Office and Consumer Products business. 
Starting with Retail Branding and Information Solutions, sales decreased 6% on an abrupt decline in unit volumes across all customer groups and geographies, which pressured profits in this high variable margin business. A major factor in the order decline was the dramatic run-up in material and labor cost for apparel, which impacted retailers in 2 ways. First, it caused them to be very cautious about ordering garments with higher unit costs with correspondingly higher prices, especially in an environment of uncertain consumer demand. 
Cotton prices and other material inputs peaked and then dropped rapidly in the quarter. This should cause unit costs for apparel to drop later this year. But because of that, our customers delayed or canceled orders to make sure they did not end up with large inventories of higher cost goods. Combined, these dynamics have the most impact on apparel, destined for the mass-market channel in the U.S., with unit volumes down significantly due to the magnitude of price increases on lower-priced garments, as well as the lack of consumer buying power at lower-income levels.
While we expected a somewhat softer season this year due to the anticipated higher costs, we do not expect a rapid reduction in cotton and 
Other input prices. We expect the softness to continue until later this year, and that's when retailers place their orders for the 2012 season.
Turning to Pressure-sensitive Materials, it seems clear that overall economic activity slowed during the second quarter. We serve a wide range of end markets in Pressure-sensitive Materials, including food, durable goods and health and personal care. We also sell thousands of label converters all over the world, and that makes it difficult to link our sales to end consumer sales. However, historically, this business has been a leading indicator for economic activity.
Labeling and Packaging Materials saw unit volume decline in every region, including emerging markets. Net sales on an organic basis were flat over last year because pricing actions offset the volume decline. This represents a big change from the first quarter when net sales grew almost 10%. It appears that like apparel, retailers and brands, consumer packaged goods companies are being cautious about consumer spending in the second half and are managing inventories tightly.
Label and Packaging Materials has led the industry on price increases that cover inflation, and we made progress on narrowing the price inflation gap that developed in the second half of last year. As you know, we've been pushing prices up aggressively as raw material costs have escalated. As volumes softened in June, pricing became more challenging as competitors tried to hang onto volume, and this happened especially in Europe. Now, at this point, we don't have any shared data from any of our markets, but we believe we may have lost a bit of share in the quarter as we prioritized getting our prices up. Now it's normal for us to lose a bit of share on the margin as we raise prices. So I'm confident that most of the volume losses related to the lower market demand.
Now if there is a silver lining to this market softness, it's that we don't see inflation accelerating as it has for the last 5 quarters. I'm pleased that we've recovered most of the margin loss caused by inflation. It is likely we'll have to raise prices though in certain geographies and product lines to offset some of the remaining gap.
It's tough to predict how the rest of the year will play out. We have limited forward visibility in this business since we shipped out 80% of our orders in a 2-day window. We don't know yet if the lower activity level represents a short slowdown or the beginning of a more protracted trend. Our other Pressure-Sensitive business, Graphics and Reflective solutions had a great quarter, led by strong sales of new cast film products. 
Office and Consumer Products volumes, sales and margin declined year-over-year as expected. We're  on track to launch new products in the second half, which combined with the back-to-school season, will help Office and Consumer Products improve sales trends and meet its full year margin targets.
Given the trends in the quarter, we're assuming that a continuation of the market slowdown through year end is a real possibility, and our updated guidance reflects that. We built in some very modest improvement in volumes but also uncertainty about when in the second half it might occur. 
We're cutting expenses, tightening our belts and reducing capital expenditures by $25 million, as well as evaluating additional opportunities to improve productivity. Our goal is to reduce expenses without sacrificing investment for the future.
Finally, although we've reduce guidance for free cash flow for the year, we remain focused on generating substantial free cash flow in the second half. We're committed to maintaining our strong balance sheet and returning more cash to shareholders. 
And now Mitch will take you through the details of the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through to Slide 9. Sales in the second quarter were up as reported by 3% but down about 2% organically. As Dean discussed, volume was the driver of the organic sales decline, particularly in our Pressure-se
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 6 and talking through to Slide 9. Sales in the second quarter were up as reported by 3% but down about 2% organically. As Dean discussed, volume was the driver of the organic sales decline, particularly in our Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Branding and Information Solutions segment. Volumes for the company were down approximately 5%, dropping up dramatically in June, historically, the largest month in the quarter. The volume declines, of course, impacted our second quarter consolidated operating margin. Our operating margin of 8.2% was down 80 basis points from last year, as the negative impact of lower volume was partially offset by a reduction in employee-related costs, including lower expense from incentive compensation.
We've talked a lot about rising raw material cost over the last few quarters and they remain high. We've made great progress in offsetting inflation by implementing the productivity initiatives and price increases that we've talking about during our past few earnings reports. 
As for marketing, general and administrative expense, it declined versus last year due to lower employee-related costs. Last quarter, we talked about stepping up growth in IT infrastructure related investments. We're still making investments in our most promising and critical initiatives while we reduce costs across the rest of the company, both through structural changes and general belt-tightening.
Before getting into the segment, I want to point out that our year-to-date adjusted tax rate increased from 23% to 29%, largely reflecting an increased portion of our profit now expected to be in higher tax rate jurisdiction. 
I also want to comment on our year-to-date free cash flow, which included a net outflow in the second quarter, very atypical for us. This net outflow is largely due to the combination of lower operating results and additional $25 million pension payments and changes in working capital. 
Now the changes -- the working capital changes primarily relates to the timing of cash payments for inventories. While we reduced inventories in the second quarter from the relatively high levels in Q1, the benefits of free cash flow will occur in the third quarter. These working capital changes and pension payments, while negative to the quarter in the first half, are not expected to impact the full year.
Now I'm sure you've noticed that our fee cash flow was out-of-sync with earnings in the quarter. This is largely because of reduction in our expectations for employee-related costs in 2011 are noncash this year and will not benefit free cash flow until the first quarter of next year.
Turning to Slide 10. Our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment delivered roughly flat organic sales growth, driven by declines in volume, largely offset by pricing. PSM's volume reflected year-over-year decline in all of Label and Packaging Materials regions and the most categories. Volume in Graphics and Reflective solutions was up in the quarter. Dean shared with you our insights to the volumes in the segment, so I won't repeat them here. PSM's operating margin in the quarter was down 20 basis points year-over-year, reflecting the decline in volume and of lower employee-related costs. Sequentially, margin benefited from our narrowing of the price inflation gap.
Retail Branding and Information Solutions turned in a 6% decline in organic sales in the second quarter, traditionally, this segment's largest quarter of the year. The lower sales were due to lower unit volumes reflecting the softness in the market for our apparel units that Dean discussed earlier. 
With the decline in volumes, the relatively high operating leverage in this business worked against us this quarter, more than you can see in the 140 basis point drop due to our lower employee-related costs. Dean covered Office and Consumer products, which came in as expected. The second quarter is a seasonally higher quarter for this business relative to Q1, as it includes part of the back-to-school season which concludes in Q3. We continue to expect margins for this business to be in the upper single digits for the full year. And our Other Specialty Converting businesses delivered flat sales growth in the quarter, with margins up 90 basis points from last year.
Moving on to the outlook for 2011. On Slide 13, we summarized the key factors that we expect to contribute to our P&L and cash flow in 2011. Slide 14 has our EPS and free cash flow guidance. I'll highlight just a few key assumptions that have changed from what we've discussed last quarter. 
We now estimate organic sales growth in 2011 of approximately 1.5% to 3.5%, a big difference from the 7% assumption we made last quarter. Our current uncertainty about the market causes us to provide a pretty wide range for the top line in the second half.
We've increased our restructuring actions since last quarter and have accordingly increased our expectation of the cost to implement these actions. Annualized savings associated with 2011 restructuring actions are expected to total approximately $40 million. That's about 1/3 of the benefits to be realized this year. We continue to evaluate further opportunities to reduce cost, potentially including additional restructuring action, and we've reduced our estimate for capital expenditures for the year by $25 million. 
Based on estimated sales and other assumptions, including a list of factors, we now expect adjusted earnings per share in 2011 of $2.45 to $2.75, and free cash flow of $250 million to $275 million.
Notwithstanding the recent slowdown, we are confident about our position and prospects. Our businesses have market-leading positions with clear competitive advantages. And even with our lowered guidance for free cash flow in 2011, we will maintain our financial strength, achieving our targeted debt level again later this year, and then increasing our return of cash to shareholders. 
Now I would be happy to take your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011

componenttext: I was curious, Dean, perhaps if you could help us to breakdown a 5% organic volume decline into attributable factors, and maybe you can help us to rule some out. Do you think there was any demand in the first quarter that borrowed strength in the second quarter? And do you think there's demand in the second quarter that is perhaps being shifted to the third quarter? And I think you did mention there may have been some competitive behavior, was that as much as 100 or 200 basis points? Anymore color you can offer on kind of the variances in the factors would be really helpful.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Peter. So I'd say there might have been a very small amount of shifting, and I can't really quantify it because most of the evidence we have is anecdotal at this point. So in Retail Branding and Information Services, the first -- some of the first q
componenttext: Sure, Peter. So I'd say there might have been a very small amount of shifting, and I can't really quantify it because most of the evidence we have is anecdotal at this point. So in Retail Branding and Information Services, the first -- some of the first quarter sales, I think, were stronger than we had anticipated in the quarter because frankly, people were just trying to get ahead of some of these unit costs that were coming in because people at that point expected input costs to keep going up at that time. So they were kind of buying early in the inflationary environment. That, of course, shifted pretty dramatically in the second quarter once cotton prices started to collapse. We may have had a little bit of pre-buying in the Pressure-sensitive Materials business, but it would have been very small as a percentage of the total, so not really meaningful. And as part of the share position, we did see, in Europe, typically June is a pretty strong month for the Labeling and Packaging Materials business there because people are doing a lot of work before the summer holidays. The Food business tends to be very strong at that point of view, and we just didn't see the surge that we normally saw. And some competitors, I think,  in a weakening environment, just could have deferred to delay some price increases. The problem is we don't have any market share data and we wont have it for a few weeks. I wish I could be more precise on that, but we just can't at this point.

componenttextpreview: Okay, and if I'm understanding what happened, would it be logical that if cotton were to bottom and turn the other direction that, that would bring buyers off the sidelines?
componenttext: Okay, and if I'm understanding what happened, would it be logical that if cotton were to bottom and turn the other direction that, that would bring buyers off the sidelines?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's actually -- you've seen some articles about this lately in the trade press, but also in places like the Wall Street Journal. So cotton prices are already down. The problem is that cotton has not yet been turned into gray goods, which c
componenttext: Well, I think, it's actually -- you've seen some articles about this lately in the trade press, but also in places like the Wall Street Journal. So cotton prices are already down. The problem is that cotton has not yet been turned into gray goods, which can be put into yarn and fabrics, and that really won't happen until later this year. So most companies are anticipating lower cotton costs and unit costs from a material perspective for 2012. They wont start ordering those products from us until very late in the third and in the fourth quarter. That's when we really start to see our fourth quarter surge in that business. So, yes -- I do see that, and I think there was actually, even in an article in the Wall Street Journal, about some people trying to keep their prices up by just adding units to their packs as a way of giving more to the consumer instead of giving it in price, giving it in unit volumes, which would be okay with us by the way. That would be a good trend.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the primary reason for the change in the tax rate is related to the geographic income mix. So we now have -- when we lowered our income projections for the year, it was lowered disproportionately in low tax rate jurisdiction. So that's what caused
componenttext: Yes, so the primary reason for the change in the tax rate is related to the geographic income mix. So we now have -- when we lowered our income projections for the year, it was lowered disproportionately in low tax rate jurisdiction. So that's what caused the increase in the tax rate. The discrete events was -- we commented there that was just about 20% or so of the change. So a very small component of the overall change on the tax rate was around some planning matters that we were looking out for later in the year that we're not going to implement, given the current environment. So primarily geographic mix. When you ask about it going forward, it depends on -- if you're talking about for the near term, it really depends on what the geographic mix is going to be and really what kind of environment we're in. But I'd say, it's still mid- to perhaps a high 20% range.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Going back to the pre-announcement from last week and the guidance that's for the year, you never actually gave explicit guidance on a quarterly basis. So just to clarify, what did you assume the 2Q EPS would be initially? Roughly $1 A share, is that in t
componenttext: Going back to the pre-announcement from last week and the guidance that's for the year, you never actually gave explicit guidance on a quarterly basis. So just to clarify, what did you assume the 2Q EPS would be initially? Roughly $1 A share, is that in the ballpark?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We had something less than that, actually. It's around $0.90.
componenttext: We had something less than that, actually. It's around $0.90.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: $0.90, all right. And just based on what you're saying on the macro side. Thinking back to Office Products, 1Q took a big hit just from a pre-buying 4Q, if I remember correctly. And you're also supporting some new product launches, et cetera.  Just given
componenttext: $0.90, all right. And just based on what you're saying on the macro side. Thinking back to Office Products, 1Q took a big hit just from a pre-buying 4Q, if I remember correctly. And you're also supporting some new product launches, et cetera.  Just given the weakness on the micro that you seem to be cautious on, are you scaling back some of those product launches?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we're not. In fact, Office Products, the current back-to-school view is still where we talked about in the last quarter. I think it will be flat, flattish, maybe down 1% for us this year. But most of the new product launches, we've got orders for and
componenttext: No, we're not. In fact, Office Products, the current back-to-school view is still where we talked about in the last quarter. I think it will be flat, flattish, maybe down 1% for us this year. But most of the new product launches, we've got orders for and placed, and again, some -- only a few products have hit the stores so far. We'll start to see a lot more in late third quarter and during the fourth quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then going back to...
componenttext: Okay, and then going back to...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We pretty much already -- we've got the plan. We're executing, manufacturing, et cetera. So we're all locked and loaded, ready to go.
componenttext: We pretty much already -- we've got the plan. We're executing, manufacturing, et cetera. So we're all locked and loaded, ready to go.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then moving onto your comments in the press release on returning cash to shareholders, on the share buyback issue, specifically. Even in what seems like a subpar year now, you're still going to generate a fair amount of cash flow opposed your di
componenttext: Okay, and then moving onto your comments in the press release on returning cash to shareholders, on the share buyback issue, specifically. Even in what seems like a subpar year now, you're still going to generate a fair amount of cash flow opposed your dividend. You have a share buyback authorization out there, should we expect any sort of meaningful purchase in 2011, and if not, why not?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you know Ghansham -- we never comment on the timing or amount of share repurchases, but I'll reemphasize that we're committed to returning more cash to shareholders.
componenttext: As you know Ghansham -- we never comment on the timing or amount of share repurchases, but I'll reemphasize that we're committed to returning more cash to shareholders.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let me put that around, are you comfortable with where your balance sheet is right now?
componenttext: Well, let me put that around, are you comfortable with where your balance sheet is right now?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're comfortable overall with where our balance sheet is. One of the things you got to look at, we commented that in Q4 we achieved the target leverage position that we were seeking. Because of the seasonality of our cash flow, debt will go up during the
componenttext: We're comfortable overall with where our balance sheet is. One of the things you got to look at, we commented that in Q4 we achieved the target leverage position that we were seeking. Because of the seasonality of our cash flow, debt will go up during the year, did more so than usual this year. But when you look at the second half cash flow, we'll be looking to get back again to those leverage ratios and leverage position, and then return more cash to shareholders. Your point, there's enough -- if you look at the free cash flow and you triangulate how much debt reduction we need from our current position, there would be sufficient on our current guidance for share repurchases.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John P. McNulty with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John P. McNulty with Credit Suisse.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. On the raw material front, did you say you were 100% caught up at this point, or are you still working to catch up throughout the rest of the year?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. On the raw material front, did you say you were 100% caught up at this point, or are you still working to catch up throughout the rest of the year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've got a little bit of a gap left, and we still have some price increases plans for going forward. But they're very either product line or geography specific. So they're relatively minor. I think this is the first quarter now over the last 5 quarters w
componenttext: We've got a little bit of a gap left, and we still have some price increases plans for going forward. But they're very either product line or geography specific. So they're relatively minor. I think this is the first quarter now over the last 5 quarters where we haven't announced additional inflation expectations over and above what we've had. So the environment we're in is more flattened out. And again, there are still just a couple of areas where we need to execute price increases to fill in that gap.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then as best you can tell in the Pressure-sensitive area, I mean, it sounds like there has been some increased kind of competitive pressure. Have you seen your, I guess, major competitor or competitors raise price yet? Or is it -- was it just a
componenttext: Okay, and then as best you can tell in the Pressure-sensitive area, I mean, it sounds like there has been some increased kind of competitive pressure. Have you seen your, I guess, major competitor or competitors raise price yet? Or is it -- was it just a function that they were delayed? Or are they just not actively going that way and they're actually pushing more for share?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've had -- every one of our competitors has felt the same inflation pressure that we felt. And so, what we've seen is competitors following and raising prices in their markets. We just had heard an announcement earlier -- I'm sorry, late last we
componenttext: I think we've had -- every one of our competitors has felt the same inflation pressure that we felt. And so, what we've seen is competitors following and raising prices in their markets. We just had heard an announcement earlier -- I'm sorry, late last week where one of our competitors in Europe has announced price increases again for certain geographies. So I still think that the competitors in this industry want to make money, and they know they've got to get prices up in a time of rising raw material costs. I think it was kind of a little sloppy in June in Europe, specifically, when the volume shortfalls. We had a marketable volume shortfall, so some folks sometimes on the margins -- some competitors feel that they're better off trying to protect volume in the short term rather than raise prices. So we've seen this before. I do want to point out though that sequentially, we improved margins again in this sector. I mean, that was a priority for us to fill that gap. And all we've talking about the last 4 quarters has been inflation. Unfortunately, now we're talking about volume. So I think we've done a reasonable job of executing. And the team has done good job of executing, getting prices up in our key markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just one last question. Just in terms of your customer base, I know -- I guess, in certain areas where you've seen a lot of inflation and then when prices start to rollover, you saw a de-stocking around that. Do your customers typically de-
componenttext: Okay, and then just one last question. Just in terms of your customer base, I know -- I guess, in certain areas where you've seen a lot of inflation and then when prices start to rollover, you saw a de-stocking around that. Do your customers typically de-stock and try to play that pricing game, or is that something that we really don't see like in the Pressure-sensitive area?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: For label printers and converters, it's tough for them to do because they're in a custom business. They don't always know what their customers are going to order, so they don't hold a lot of finished goods inventory, and most of these customers are relati
componenttext: For label printers and converters, it's tough for them to do because they're in a custom business. They don't always know what their customers are going to order, so they don't hold a lot of finished goods inventory, and most of these customers are relatively small. So and they don't have a lot of space, so it's really tough for them to stock up either on a lot of our product or go to reduction. So we don't really see that kind of behavior. You see it again on the fringe.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of John E. Roberts with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of John E. Roberts with Buckingham Research.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can your apparel customers wait to see back-to-school sales before deciding what to do for the holiday season?
componenttext: Can your apparel customers wait to see back-to-school sales before deciding what to do for the holiday season?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, they'll -- I mean, they are always looking forward. They are already planning the 2012 season. And in their mix will go things like what will apparel cost look like on a go-forward basis, what's the consumer appetite for spending, and certainly the
componenttext: Sure, they'll -- I mean, they are always looking forward. They are already planning the 2012 season. And in their mix will go things like what will apparel cost look like on a go-forward basis, what's the consumer appetite for spending, and certainly the back-to-school apparel season for them will be an indicator of how confident the consumer will be and how much discounting they have to do during that specific season. So it's one of the inputs they look at to judge what they're open to buy numbers will be for 2012.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, just to clarify, the latest Q3 and Q4 spend is usually purchases from us or for the spring season next year. I think if you were asking -- [indiscernible] for holiday? The answer is no, not so much.
componenttext: John, just to clarify, the latest Q3 and Q4 spend is usually purchases from us or for the spring season next year. I think if you were asking -- [indiscernible] for holiday? The answer is no, not so much.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, but they're likely to be sitting on their hands at least until Labor Day period, I guess, to get some sense or clarity on their visibility?
componenttext: Okay, but they're likely to be sitting on their hands at least until Labor Day period, I guess, to get some sense or clarity on their visibility?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This typically is not high ordering season for us anyway, okay? So what's in the stores now for back-to-school is already there. And we might get a few chase orders, that type of thing, but the activity level is actually relatively low in the third quarte
componenttext: This typically is not high ordering season for us anyway, okay? So what's in the stores now for back-to-school is already there. And we might get a few chase orders, that type of thing, but the activity level is actually relatively low in the third quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to think of when might have some visibility yourself in the trend, whether things pick up or not, you sound like you wouldn't expect it for a while.
componenttext: I'm just trying to think of when might have some visibility yourself in the trend, whether things pick up or not, you sound like you wouldn't expect it for a while.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Late third quarter. By the next earnings call, we'll have a decent feel for what apparel and retail open to buy and sentiment is.
componenttext: Late third quarter. By the next earnings call, we'll have a decent feel for what apparel and retail open to buy and sentiment is.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, did you make all your compensation accruals adjustments in the second quarter for your lower budget now? Or will you wait closer to year end to reduce bonus accruals and things like that, that you'd have to do if you don't make plan?
componenttext: Okay, did you make all your compensation accruals adjustments in the second quarter for your lower budget now? Or will you wait closer to year end to reduce bonus accruals and things like that, that you'd have to do if you don't make plan?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We adjust them each quarter based on our forecast for the year. And so in Q2, it was -- we did not accrue as much the normal amount for Q2. We also reduced some of the accruals that we made in Q1.We reversed them Q2.
componenttext:
We adjust them each quarter based on our forecast for the year. And so in Q2, it was -- we did not accrue as much the normal amount for Q2. We also reduced some of the accruals that we made in Q1.
We reversed them Q2.

componenttext: Okay, you reversed them in Q1?
