headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. And welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended, October 1, 2011. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today, through
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. And welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended, October 1, 2011. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today, through midnight Pacific time, October 30. To access the replay, please dial 1(800) 633 8284 or international callers, 1(402) 977-9140. The conference ID number is 21496536. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's head of Investor Relations. You may go ahead, sir

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation entitled Third Quarter Financial Review and Analysis. Most of the documents were furnished today with our 8-K
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation entitled Third Quarter Financial Review and Analysis. Most of the documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. Let me remind you that these unaudited results are preliminary as we have not yet filed our 10-Q.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes the interest expense, restructuring charges and other items, included in the other expense line of our P&L. These items tend to be fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on non-GAAP operating margin, which reflects pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. 
The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release. We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about future performance and financial results. 
These forward-looking statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. 
The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we provided today, along with our 2010 Form 10-K and 2011 Form 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations. 
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; and Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. The soft volume trends we saw in the second quarter continued into the third quarter and caused sales ex-currency to decline 2%. Unit demand in all key markets continues to reflect both consumer confidence, which is translating into tight in
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. The soft volume trends we saw in the second quarter continued into the third quarter and caused sales ex-currency to decline 2%. Unit demand in all key markets continues to reflect both consumer confidence, which is translating into tight inventory management throughout the supply chain. And we expect this trend to continue into the fourth quarter. 
I am pleased that despite the lower volume and ongoing high raw material costs, operating results were in line with the third quarter of last year. The combination of continued pricing discipline, accelerated productivity and lower employee related costs essentially offset the impact of lower unit volume at the EBIT line. At the net income level, the change in our tax rate had a significant impact, which Mitch will discuss in more detail.
We made solid progress in generating free cash flow in the third quarter as well. Our teams did a good job of tightening expenses while at the same time protecting investments in innovation and new products. 
As the past quarter demonstrated, we are launching an increasing number of new products to enhance our competitive advantage and enable faster growth once the economic situation improves. 
Turning to the businesses. Organic sales growth for the Pressure-sensitive Materials segment was 2%. Volume in the quarter was still soft, but we did see a slight improvement in the trend over the second quarter. Margins expanded year-over-year as the impact of price increases and higher productivity offset the impact of inflation.
The recent Labelexpo show in Brussels was well attended and customers were very enthusiastic about all the new products we had in our stand. However, European customers were understandably concerned about the next few quarters due to the uncertain economic conditions in that region. But even in the slowdown, or maybe even because of it, converters were very interested in our new technology and products and that's because they see innovation as a way to grow faster. 
Our Labeling and Packaging Materials business introduced 16 your products with some significant innovation. We're specially excited about ThinStream, a new line of material that is 50% thinner than anything else on the market and which enables better economics to penetrate high volume food and beverage segments. 
We also introduced a new phase film with lower caliber and greater confirmability to better meet the needs for more sustainable lower-cost materials in household and personal care segment.
By wrapping up this segment, sales at Graphics and Reflective Solutions were flat compared with last year ex-currency, Butier lower than in the second quarter, which indicates a downturn in advertising and promotional spending. 
Retail Branding and Information Solutions continued to feel the impact of unit volume decline and high apparel input costs, which is cotton work their way through this retail supply chain. We do expect unit volumes to gradually improve as lower input cost begin to come into play subject, of course, to retailers getting confidence in consumer spending. We are projecting an improvement in volume trends in Q4 as retailers begin to order for this season.
We continue to see adoption of RFID unit sagging, which is up more than 50% from last year. Additionally, we expanded our new line of heat transfer solutions called agility, which enables apparel brands to enhance garment exteriors with new high definition graphics that was not available on the market before. 
Even with a 7% decline in organic sales RBIS maintain margins during the quarter through our ELS productivity programs, lower employee related costs and an acceleration of some plan restructuring. This positions us well for margin expansion when unit volume recovers. 
Office and Consumer Products volume, sales and margin declined as expected due to weak end market demand. One notable event for the business was the partnership we announced with Martha Stewart leaving on media and Staples for a line of home organization products that will be available for consumers starting in early 2012. We do anticipate sales from this new line in the fourth quarter of 2011 as we prepare for that launch.
Summing up for the total company, we expect volume to be the story in the fourth quarter as well although we saw a slight improvement in volume trends in September, we believe that any increases in the fourth quarter will be marginally at that especially in Europe. 
We reduced our full year guidance to reflect this volume outlook as well as the increase in our tax rate. Our employees have done a very good job of reducing expenses and focusing on maximizing free cash flow. And we'll continue to do so. 
We also did some targeted restructuring during the quarter to reduce fixed costs. We're always looking for ways to improve productivity, including restructuring and we're evaluating further opportunities to do so. 
At the same time, we're continuing to develop end market innovative new products. Now Mitch will take you through the quarter in more detail.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking through to Slide 7. Sales in the third quarter were up as reported by 4%, but down about 2% organically. As Dean discussed, we saw volume decline across all segments. Volumes for the company were down just
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking through to Slide 7. Sales in the third quarter were up as reported by 4%, but down about 2% organically. 
As Dean discussed, we saw volume decline across all segments. Volumes for the company were down just over 4%, somewhat below the low end of our expectations. Negative trend in demand lessened late in the quarter with sales being roughly flat on an organic basis in September. 
Our third quarter operating margin was relatively flat with last year as the negative impact of the lower volume was mostly offset by a reduction in employee related costs, including lower expense for incentive compensation. 
Prices for the specialized raw materials that we buy remain high, but are stabilizing. As we discussed last quarter, we've essentially offset the raw material inflation that we began to experience mid-last year by implementing the productivity initiatives and price increases that we've been talking about for the past few quarters.
As for marketing, general and administrative expense, it declined versus last year due to lower employee related costs and productivity, partially offset by currency. We're reducing cost across the company through both restructuring and general belt-tightening while we continue to protect our investments in growth that Dean discussed earlier. 
Next let me elaborate on our tax rate. Our year-to-date adjusted tax rate increased from 23% to 34%. The increase in the expected tax rate for this year was the key reason for the short fall in third quarter EPS and along with lower volume is a key contributing factor to our revised earnings guidance for the year. 
The primary reasons for the increased tax rate is our reduced expectation for pretax income outside the U.S. This impacts us in 2 ways. First, lower tax rates in certain jurisdictions outside the U.S. are achieved only when we pass certain income thresholds. And second, lower pretax income diminishes our ability to utilize tax loss carry forwards and other tax credits. Another factor relates to discrete tax events, which we now anticipate will have negative impact on the rate this year.
If pretax earnings continues at the current level, we would expect our ongoing tax rate to be in the low '30s in the midterm. As earnings increase about certain income threshold outside the U.S., we would expect the tax rate to be modestly below this range. Now these comments related to the effective tax rate. The ultimate goal of our tax findings is to reduce the amount of tax that is actually paid in any given year as we measure this through the cash tax rate. 
Our cash tax rate have been in the upper 30% range for the past few years, and have been trending down modestly. We expect the tax -- the cash tax rate to again be in this upper 20% range and continue the downward trend in 2011 and for the midterm.
Now before getting into the segment, I want to comment on our free cash flow. In the first half of the year, our free cash flow was well below prior year level due to lower operating results and higher working capital, as well as the timing of pension payments. 
Looking at the third quarter, our free cash flow came in at $189 million. This is in line with our expectations and well ahead of last year due to the significant progress we made in Q3 in returning to more typical working capital levels. 
Turning to Slide 8, our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment delivered 2% organic sales growth, driven by pricing and partially offset by lower volume. PSM to volume in the third quarter was down approximately 2.5%, an improvement over the second quarter's 5% volume decline. This improvement in the trend reflects a moderation in Label and Packaging Materials declines in Europe and an uptick in Asia-Pacific, which we turn to positive volume growth in the quarter. 
In addition to experiencing general softness in our markets, we also commented last quarter that we thought we lost some share in lower margin categories in Europe, well, we in fact did. While we do yet have market or shared data for Q3, we believe that we may have regained a modest amount of the share in the quarter. 
And my last point on sales in PSM relates to Graphics and Reflective solutions. Volumes in this business held up in Q2, but have now experienced a decline, due primarily to softness in Europe. Well remember that this businesses is more cyclical in nature than PSM's larger business, Label and Packaging Materials.
PSM's operating margin increased 50 basis points from prior year as the impact of lower volume was more than offset by lower employee related costs. Our pricing and cost reduction actions have offset the inflation that we began to experience mid last year. The pricing on raw material cost is now stabilizing, we feel that we've achieved a good position on the price cost front in PSM.
Retail Branding and Information Solutions sales were down 7% on an organic basis in the third quarter. Lower sales were due to a continuation of the trend we saw in Q2 with lower volume reflecting unit softness in the apparel market that Dean discussed earlier. As in the second quarter, the declines were most pronounced among mass-market retailers. RBIS margins were flat in the quarter as the negative impact of volume was offset by productivity and lower employee related costs. In consumer products came in as expected. The third quarter is typically a seasonally higher quarter for this business as it includes part of the back-to-school season, which starts in Q2. 
The operating margin in this business declined due primarily to the effect of lower volume and higher raw material costs, partially offset by lower advertising spend and employee related costs. We continue to expect margins for this business to be in the upper single digits for the full year.
And our Other Specialty Converting businesses delivered modest sales growth in the quarter, driven by pricing from lower volume. Margins were down due to the lower volume partially offset by productivity initiatives. 
Moving onto the outlook for 2011. On Slide 11, we summarized the key factors that we expect to contribute to our P&L and cash flow in 2011. Slide 12 has our EPS and free cash flow guidance. I'll highlight just a few key assumptions that have changed from what we discussed last quarter. 
We now estimate organic sales growth in 2011 to be roughly flat. Reduction primarily reflects a change to our assumptions for the fourth quarter. The increase our restructuring actions since last quarter and have accordingly increased our expectation of the cost to implement these actions. 
Annualized savings associated with 2011 restructuring actions are now expected to total approximately $55 million, which is about 1/4 of the benefit to be realized this year. We continue to evaluate further opportunities to reduce costs, potentially including additional restructuring actions.
We already discussed our increase in our expected tax rate for the year, that is the negative tax rate impact from our lower outlook for pretax income and other discrete events. And we made an additional $10 million pension contribution to the U.S. plan in the third quarter and we expect to contribute another $10 million in the fourth quarter. Full year pension contributions will approximate the level of last year.
Based on estimated sales and other assumptions, including the listed factors, we now expect adjusted earnings per share in 2011 of $2.15 to $2.30 and free cash flow of $215 million to $235 million. The low end of our EPS guidance assumes volume trends in Q4 that are consistent with what we experienced in Q3 and the high end reflects volume trends consistent with what we saw in September. Now, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from the line of George Staphos, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from the line of George Staphos, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I have a question first on the tax rate. Mitch, would it be possible to parse the affect of the geographic dispersion of income or the change relative to your expectations versus what was the discrete tax item and can you provide a bit more detail
componenttext: I guess I have a question first on the tax rate. Mitch, would it be possible to parse the affect of the geographic dispersion of income or the change relative to your expectations versus what was the discrete tax item and can you provide a bit more detail on what is that discrete tax item.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, so couple of things, as far as what is the amount of discrete tax items versus the effect of just lower pretax income to answer that part of the question first. It depends we said that the full year guidance is expected to be in the low to mid 30s,
componenttext: Well, so couple of things, as far as what is the amount of discrete tax items versus the effect of just lower pretax income to answer that part of the question first. It depends we said that the full year guidance is expected to be in the low to mid 30s, it depends where we ultimately settle out, but roughly about half of that is from the discrete items that we're flagging here. As far as what the discrete items are, they're specifically related to just as certain tax audits get finished out throughout the year, we anticipated that some of those complete more favorably than they actually end up in foreign jurisdictions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: It's just a catch up. What he does, it gets the year to date rate up to 34%.

componenttext: Okay. The last question on this, then I'll have one quickly follow-on, and turn it over. As we look out for next year, it would appear we're building into somewhat more of a structurally higher tax rate that we should forecast. Could that be the low to mid '30s on  agoing forward basis?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, my comments were fixed income were to stay at the current levels, I'm not giving guidance, but if they were, we'll sustainably be at the low 30% range. As pretax income arises, we expect the geographic mix and our ability to take advantage of the lo
componenttext: Well, my comments were fixed income were to stay at the current levels, I'm not giving guidance, but if they were, we'll sustainably be at the low 30% range. As pretax income arises, we expect the geographic mix and our ability to take advantage of the lower tax jurisdictions would increase and that's what the tax rate with moderate somewhat from that level. Let's get back to the upper 20s that we talked about before.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And in terms of the commentary on RBIS, that volume declines in Europe, what do you think we are? Do you do see a similar volume decline in the second quarter, is it worse now, is there any sort of parallel between what they're seeing rig
componenttext: Okay, all right. And in terms of the commentary on RBIS, that volume declines in Europe, what do you think we are? Do you do see a similar volume decline in the second quarter, is it worse now, is there any sort of parallel between what they're seeing right now versus the U.S. in '08 and '09?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, for RBIS, it got sequentially a little bit worse. Q3 is normally not a strong quarter for us anyway, and I think that many retailers continue to delay orders waiting for some of those lower input costs to flow into pricing program that will be o
componenttext: Actually, for RBIS, it got sequentially a little bit worse. Q3 is normally not a strong quarter for us anyway, and I think that many retailers continue to delay orders waiting for some of those lower input costs to flow into pricing program that will be ordered now mainly for the spring, little bit of the summer season. And that the orders will take in the fourth quarter. Actually, the U.S. has been marginally worse for us. Actually, quite a bit worse than Europe. Europe has been better, it's downward trend has been a lot less. Part of that is because I believe we're taking some market share. Part of that is because many of the retailers and brand owners we serve in Europe, that are based in Europe also have a global footprint. So they're not just focused on European retail sales. And finally, we just don't have as much impact from mass market. We just don't have that high share of mass market retailers in Europe as we do in the U.S. So all of those factors together actually make Europe appear to be okay. And so far, we haven't really seen a change in that trajectory.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just finally, Mitch, how should we think about working capital for the full year?
componenttext: Got it. And just finally, Mitch, how should we think about working capital for the full year?

componenttextpreview: For the full year, we expect to maintain working capital productivity we had last year and you saw the first half these apps bit from that level and that we recovered a good amount of that in Q3. So we expect to recover the previous levels we had. And tha
componenttext: For the full year, we expect to maintain working capital productivity we had last year and you saw the first half these apps bit from that level and that we recovered a good amount of that in Q3. So we expect to recover the previous levels we had. And that's focused on operating working capital. One thing to point out is we have talked about lower incentive based compensation, so there will obviously be fewer accruals this year. So the impacts working capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. It does look like raw material seem to have leveled off and in some cases are starting to come down is, especially in the propylene and acrylic base side. In terms of the pricing you've been getting to offset the raw mate
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. It does look like raw material seem to have leveled off and in some cases are starting to come down is, especially in the propylene and acrylic base side. In terms of the pricing you've been getting to offset the raw materials, what is your belief in terms of your ability to hold the pricing or and or when you might start giving it back?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a great question, John. First of all, I want to give our team, especially in our Materials business full credit for doing a great job in managing in that inflationary environment. We basically have a been able to close the gap and that's requ
componenttext: Well, that's a great question, John. First of all, I want to give our team, especially in our Materials business full credit for doing a great job in managing in that inflationary environment. We basically have a been able to close the gap and that's required a significant amount of work, during the quarter, or during the last 4 quarters. The inflationary environment I would characterize is stable. Some of the input cost have gone down, but still some of the specialty materials that we buy, we haven't seen lot of relief on pricing. I would just characterize the market is roughly stable at this point. And right now, and certainly throughout the third quarter, there's been -- I would characterize the market as kind of stable from a pricing perspective and so we don't see necessarily anybody really driving for volume by trying to lower prices right now and I think that's because input costs are still relatively high.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just with regard to pension it sounds like you're making some incremental contributions. Can you give us an update, I know pensions are obviously taken a decent hit with where the discount rates are and how the markets are looking. H
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just with regard to pension it sounds like you're making some incremental contributions. Can you give us an update, I know pensions are obviously taken a decent hit with where the discount rates are and how the markets are looking. How should we be thinking about incremental pension expenses for 2012, if things kind of just stop right now?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still going through that evaluation given the change in discount rates. One of the things that we know is regardless of what those assumptions are, that assets have taken a hit overall this year and so that's one of the reasons for us to incre
componenttext: Well, we're still going through that evaluation given the change in discount rates. One of the things that we know is regardless of what those assumptions are, that assets have taken a hit overall this year and so that's one of the reasons for us to increase the amount of contributions. As you'll recall we froze, the define benefit plan in the U.S. at the end of last year and since then we said we had a concerted effort over the next few years to get much closer to fully funded and start to shift the asset base to more conservative assets to take out some of the volatility going forward. As far as exactly what it looks like next year, there's still a lot of discussion about what the return on assets assumption should be, as well as the discount rates. So you would expect a modest headwind going into next year, though.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: Can you let us know what the cash restructuring outlays would look like in the fourth quarter?

componenttextpreview: In the fourth quarter, specifically, you got about $35 million investment for the full year. I don't  have that right in front me, Jeff. We can go over that later, but it's going to be probably about half of that.
componenttext: In the fourth quarter, specifically, you got about $35 million investment for the full year. I don't  have that right in front me, Jeff. We can go over that later, but it's going to be probably about half of that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: About half of that, okay. And from a strategic standpoint, is the idea in the fourth quarter to run your Pressure Sensitive business at a relatively low operating rate in order to really work down your inventories, and then see what happens to the raw mat
componenttext: About half of that, okay. And from a strategic standpoint, is the idea in the fourth quarter to run your Pressure Sensitive business at a relatively low operating rate in order to really work down your inventories, and then see what happens to the raw material market?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeffrey, we've been -- the inventory levels in pressure sensitive are actually in pretty good shape right now. The real question mark we have about inventories more to do about customer behavior. If markets conditions are soft, lot of label converter
componenttext: Yes, Jeffrey, we've been -- the inventory levels in pressure sensitive are actually in pretty good shape right now. The real question mark we have about inventories more to do about customer behavior. If markets conditions are soft, lot of label converters will simply just take the last couple of weeks of the year off and run their inventories down. And if we inventory to much, we'll have a service problems when the year turns around. So I think we've got a pretty good handle on that, but in terms of us actually trying to manipulate raw material prices by changing of inventory levels, that's generally not the way we work. We work demand forecast schedule with the flow manufacturing philosophy. So it's more related to lean operating principles than it is trying to do anything external like you're suggesting.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. I understand that the volumes are tough in office products, but from a competitive standpoint, have conditions stabilized or are they still getting tougher?
componenttext: Okay. I understand that the volumes are tough in office products, but from a competitive standpoint, have conditions stabilized or are they still getting tougher?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say they really stabilized. The last few quarters our market shares remained the same. And the only thing that -- the only category that washed here in the Label business has been the private label share. So it's been incredibly stable, actually f
componenttext: No, I'd say they really stabilized. The last few quarters our market shares remained the same. And the only thing that -- the only category that washed here in the Label business has been the private label share. So it's been incredibly stable, actually for the last 9 months, the last 3 quarters.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: So from your point of view, your office product hit some kind of low point in 2011 and you're more optimistic for '12?
componenttext: So from your point of view, your office product hit some kind of low point in 2011 and you're more optimistic for '12?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we are mainly because of the lot of new product launches that we've been recently announcing. The Martha Stewart partnership with Staples Is a significant one because it gets us into some new categories like home and home office. We have a line of s
componenttext: Well, we are mainly because of the lot of new product launches that we've been recently announcing. The Martha Stewart partnership with Staples Is a significant one because it gets us into some new categories like home and home office. We have a line of sticky notes that use transparent films that consumers seem to like. And we have some new product areas, new products in the area business builders, small office, home office type categories. So as we -- we're very consistent with the strategy, investment in innovation for new products where we said 2011 is going to be the trough year. And I don't want to give an outlook yet for 2012 because we haven't made the plan. There is obviously an impact of the overall economy and that's the one factor we can't relate to. But we are going to see significant amount of new product sales in Office and Consumer Products in the fourth quarter of this year. So it's a timely turn of event.

componenttext: To stay with office products. I thought when Genuine Parts reported that the rest of the business was 4% in the quarter and they got for up 4% in the fourth quarter as well. componenttext: We haven't really seen a huge difference on either side. They're both relatively soft. I think the contracts side of business actually at the beginning of the year was a little weaker.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Since the average tax rate is like a 34%, that must mean you have some places where it's above 34% and somewhere it's below. Where is your tax rate above 34% or do you have losses that are bottled up and that's what causes the average to be higher?
componenttext: Okay. Since the average tax rate is like a 34%, that must mean you have some places where it's above 34% and somewhere it's below. Where is your tax rate above 34% or do you have losses that are bottled up and that's what causes the average to be higher?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, so definitely we have some jurisdictions where they are above 34% a couple in mixed bag out there in a very serious diction, the 34%, remember there is a few points of the discrete items that I talked about, but certain tax audits from a few years a
componenttext: Well, so definitely we have some jurisdictions where they are above 34% a couple in mixed bag out there in a very serious diction, the 34%, remember there is a few points of the discrete items that I talked about, but certain tax audits from a few years ago, not settling out as we expected to be and so forth, and as often happens in the second half of the year. So I wouldn't look to 34% as the ongoing rate as I mentioned it's more in the low '30s and that would be high we're in a lot of countries that we have a high amount of variation between the various tax rates, depending whatever the country is installed.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: As your earnings improve, will the tax rate kind of scale down or does it step down because of that threshold effect that it will sort of jump down in a big amount at a certain threshold?
componenttext: As your earnings improve, will the tax rate kind of scale down or does it step down because of that threshold effect that it will sort of jump down in a big amount at a certain threshold?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, region by region, it can be a step function change as you start to grow earnings across the entire company because there's different impacts on various regions, you're going to see more of a slow sliding scale.
componenttext: Yes, region by region, it can be a step function change as you start to grow earnings across the entire company because there's different impacts on various regions, you're going to see more of a slow sliding scale.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly maybe, Dean, in the past you talked about the apparel industry these inventory levels. Are we back to the low levels of financial crisis kind of period in terms of these inventory at your apparel customers?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly maybe, Dean, in the past you talked about the apparel industry these inventory levels. Are we back to the low levels of financial crisis kind of period in terms of these inventory at your apparel customers?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The inventory to sales ratio stayed at historical lows now for the past couple of years, actually. Well obviously is slightly up at the financial crisis time. The biggest impact on us actually is unit volume. If you read the newspapers or the press report
componenttext: The inventory to sales ratio stayed at historical lows now for the past couple of years, actually. Well obviously is slightly up at the financial crisis time. The biggest impact on us actually is unit volume. If you read the newspapers or the press reports about how apparel retailers are doing, most of them are actually saying they're getting some sales increases, but those are all denominated in dollars because clothes are anywhere from 10% to 20% higher price right now because of input costs, unit volumes have definitely declined. Now that trend is likely to start to reverse as raw material costs have come way down. And frankly right now, a lot of the apparel manufacturers are scrambling for volumes, so I expect that again another input cost will go down. So we should see a gradual improvement as we move forward in the next couple of quarters.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our final question is from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our final question is from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: A little bit worse in the third quarter versus the second quarter, but we do expect it's still going to be negatively believe in the fourth quarter from a unit volume perspective, not as negative as the past.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the clarification there. When you take a step back and look at RBIS and Paxar, if you go back to history and look at the benefits, it should have happened from the restructuring and from the synergies. EBIT for RBIS probably in a normal envir
componenttext: I appreciate the clarification there. When you take a step back and look at RBIS and Paxar, if you go back to history and look at the benefits, it should have happened from the restructuring and from the synergies. EBIT for RBIS probably in a normal environment, you would have pegged at $200 million obviously it's been a much more difficult economic environment on the last couple of years than you would've envisioned. Given the back though, you can't change that, how do you begin to get and recover the value put into Paxar above and beyond what you've already done. I realized you'll do some further restructuring and cost cutting,  but is there anything else that you can do within the business, within the business model that can help validate the RBIS business with your overall portfolio of Avery?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest issue for us has been sales volume. Sales volume has been flat for 4 years if you just look across the past history. We overachieved on getting our synergies and cost up. So because this is high variable margin business, getting sales gr
componenttext: Well, the biggest issue for us has been sales volume. Sales volume has been flat for 4 years if you just look across the past history. We overachieved on getting our synergies and cost up. So because this is high variable margin business, getting sales growth a modern level of sales growth in this business is very important. At the same time, the playbook on a go forward basis is to invest in the business with a little bit of money for innovation of new products we watched again on the number of new products in the business that helped -- we're selling to the same customers, but we're able to for example to take our heat transfer technology, which is used on the inside of the garment for care labeling and use that on the exterior garments, which is a whole new market segment for us, frankly and we've got some unique differentiated products there. RFID also continues to track up. And then finally, the last element of what we're doing is we're getting a little more aggressive on selling those same capabilities to retailers based in countries outside of North America and Western Europe. So there's Japan, Russia, India and China, to a certain extent, Brazil. But we really do need to see sales growth in the business, that's one. I think you noticed, everybody noticed the increase in restructuring that we had announced as part of our third quarter actions. We frankly a lot of that is focused on continuing to right size the fixed costs around the Retail Branding and Information Solutions business. The playbook is continue to focus on the top line with some limited investment. We continue to work on taking capital out of the business, as well as improve productivity.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dean have the efforts to market directly to the brand owners been paying increasing dividend or has that been a little bit slower in terms of progress and hopefully it's upside for you as you hopefully consolidate to buy in gain market share from that sta
componenttext: Dean have the efforts to market directly to the brand owners been paying increasing dividend or has that been a little bit slower in terms of progress and hopefully it's upside for you as you hopefully consolidate to buy in gain market share from that standpoint?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's working. From my perspective, the ability to do branded is one key factor. The second one is RFID, we have a very large share of the RFID business, and that's the SKU level discussion, major retailers. So we are differentiated into space beca
componenttext: I think it's working. From my perspective, the ability to do branded is one key factor. The second one is RFID, we have a very large share of the RFID business, and that's the SKU level discussion, major retailers. So we are differentiated into space because of our footprint and why variety of capabilities, so we can bring to bear. And in fact, our unit volume declines in certain segments, such as vertical retailer some of the performance athletic brands, this is down very much at all. Our biggest issue this year from a decline point of view has been unit volume declines in mass market, which ahs really pulled down the average.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful, Dean. Appreciate that. Last question without necessarily projecting for next year, I realized you're not going to do that, capital spending, can you more or less keep it at the level over trend line basis, is it sustainable here? Do y
componenttext: That's very helpful, Dean. Appreciate that. Last question without necessarily projecting for next year, I realized you're not going to do that, capital spending, can you more or less keep it at the level over trend line basis, is it sustainable here? Do you think you'll have to, at some point, bring capital spending up maybe a touch closer to depreciation?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you said, George, we haven't really we're just starting the planning the process by 2012. The simple answer to your question is yes we can maintain the current rate of spend or maybe even take it down a notch or 2. I'd rather be in a position investing
componenttext: As you said, George, we haven't really we're just starting the planning the process by 2012. The simple answer to your question is yes we can maintain the current rate of spend or maybe even take it down a notch or 2. I'd rather be in a position investing though because that would mean that we're feeling much more robust about what future top line growth looks like.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mr. Scarborough, there are no further questions at this time. Sir, you may continue with your presentation or closing remarks.
componenttext: Mr. Scarborough, there are no further questions at this time. Sir, you may continue with your presentation or closing remarks.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Well, just to sum up, our focus on a go forward basis is to #1, continue to manage our expenses and drive productivity in the business. And 2, at the same time, we are going to continue to invest in innovation to differentiate our product line
componenttext: Thank you. Well, just to sum up, our focus on a go forward basis is to #1, continue to manage our expenses and drive productivity in the business. And 2, at the same time, we are going to continue to invest in innovation to differentiate our product line and to drive more top line growth. We're going to continue to generate free flow. Obviously, it's a priority to continue to strengthen our balance sheet and as well as return more cash to shareholders. Thank you very much.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. And welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended, October 1, 2011. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today, through
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. And welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended, October 1, 2011. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today, through midnight Pacific time, October 30. To access the replay, please dial 1(800) 633 8284 or for international callers, 1(402) 977-9140. The conference ID number is 21496536. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's head of Investor Relations. You may go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: .Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation entitled Third Quarter Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and
componenttext:
.
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation entitled Third Quarter Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. Let me remind you that these unaudited results are preliminary as we have not yet filed our 10-Q.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes the interest expense, restructuring charges and other items included in the other expense line of our P&L. These items tend to be fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on non-GAAP operating margin, which reflects pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. 
The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release. We also want to remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about future performance and financial results. 
These forward-looking statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. 
The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we provided today, along with our 2010 Form 10-K and 2011 Forms 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ from our expectations. 
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; and Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. The soft volume trends we saw in the second quarter continued into the third quarter and caused sales, ex-currency to decline 2%. Unit demand in all key markets continues to reflect both consumer confidence, which is translating into tight i
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. The soft volume trends we saw in the second quarter continued into the third quarter and caused sales, ex-currency to decline 2%. Unit demand in all key markets continues to reflect both consumer confidence, which is translating into tight inventory management throughout the supply chain. And we expect this trend to continue into the fourth quarter. 
I am pleased that despite the lower volume and ongoing high raw material costs, operating results were in line with the third quarter of last year. The combination of continued pricing discipline, accelerated productivity and lower employee related costs essentially offset the impact of lower unit volume at the EBIT line. At the net income level, the change in our tax rate had a significant impact, which Mitch will discuss in more detail.
We made solid progress in generating free cash flow in the third quarter as well. Our teams did a good job of tightening expenses while at the same time protecting investments in innovation and new products. 
As the past quarter demonstrated, we are launching an increasing number of new products to enhance our competitive advantage and enable faster growth once the economic situation improves. 
Turning to the businesses. Organic sales growth for the pressure-sensitive materials segment was 2%. Volume in the quarter was still soft, but we did see a slight improvement in the trend over the second quarter. Margins expanded year-over-year as the impact of price increases and higher productivity offset the impact of inflation.
The recent Labelexpo show in Brussels was well attended and customers were very enthusiastic about all the new products we had in our stand. However, European customers were understandably concerned about the next few quarters due to the uncertain economic conditions in that region. But even in a slowdown, or maybe even because of it, converters were very interested in our new technology and products, and that's because they see innovation as a way to grow faster. 
Our Labeling and Packaging Materials business introduced 16 new products with some significant innovations. We're especially excited about ThinStream, a new line of material that is 50% thinner than anything else on the market, and which enables better economics to penetrate high volume food and beverage segments. 
We also introduced a new phase film with lower caliper and greater conformability to better meet the needs for more sustainable, lower-cost materials in the household and personal care segment.
Now wrapping up this segment, sales at Graphics and Reflective Solutions were flat compared with last year ex-currency, but lower than in the second quarter, which indicates a downturn in advertising and promotional spending. 
Retail Branding and Information Solutions continue to feel the impact of unit volume decline and as high apparel input costs, which is cotton work their way through this retail supply chain. We do expect unit volumes to gradually improve as lower input cost begin to come into play subject, of course, to retailers gaining confidence in consumer spending. We are projecting an improvement in volume trends in Q4 as retailers begin to order for the spring season.
We continue to see adoption of RFID unit tagging, which is up more than 50% from last year. Additionally, we expanded our new line of heat transfer solutions called agility, which enables apparel brands to enhance garment exteriors with new high definition graphics that was not available on the market before. 
Even with a 7% decline in organic sales, RBIS maintain margins during the quarter through our ELS productivity programs, lower employee-related costs and an acceleration of some planned restructuring. This positions us well for margin expansion when unit volume recovers. 
Office and consumer products volumes, sales and margins declined as expected due to weak end market demand. One notable event for the business was the partnership we announced with Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and Staples for a line of home organization products that will be available for consumers starting in early 2012. We do anticipate sales from this new line in the fourth quarter of 2011 as we prepare for that launch.
Summing up for the total company, we expect volume to be the story in the fourth quarter as well, although we saw a slight improvement in volume trends in September, we believe that any increases in the fourth quarter will be marginal at that especially in Europe. 
We've reduced our full year guidance to reflect this volume outlook as well as the increase in our tax rate. Our employees had done a very good job of reducing expenses and focusing on maximizing free cash flow. And we'll continue to do so. 
We also did some targeted restructuring during the quarter to reduce fixed costs. We're always looking for ways to improve productivity, including restructuring, and we're evaluating further opportunities to do so. 
At the same time, we're continuing to develop end market innovative new products. Now Mitch will take you through the quarter in more detail.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking through to Slide 7. Sales in the third quarter were up as reported by 4%, but down about 2% organically. As Dean discussed, we saw a volume decline across all segments. Volumes for the company were down ju
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking through to Slide 7. Sales in the third quarter were up as reported by 4%, but down about 2% organically. 
As Dean discussed, we saw a volume decline across all segments. Volumes for the company were down just over 4%, somewhat below the low end of our expectations. The negative trend in demand lessened late in the quarter with sales being roughly flat on an organic basis in September. 
Our third quarter operating margin was relatively flat with last year as the negative impact of the lower volume was mostly offset by a reduction in employee related costs, including lower expense for incentive compensation. 
Prices for the specialized raw materials that we buy remain high, but are stabilizing. As we discussed last quarter, we've essentially offset the raw material inflation that we began to experience mid-last year by implementing the productivity initiatives and price increases that we've been talking about for the past few quarters.
As for marketing, general and administrative expense, it declined versus last year due to lower employee related costs and productivity, partially offset by currency. We are reducing cost across the company through both restructuring and general belt-tightening while we continue to protect our investments in growth that Dean discussed earlier. 
Next let me elaborate on our tax rate. Our year-to-date adjusted tax rate increased from 23% to 34%. The increase in the expected tax rate for this year was the key reason for the short fall in third quarter EPS and along with lower volume, is a key contributing factor to our revised earnings guidance for the year. 
The primary reason for the increased tax rate is our reduced expectation for pretax income outside the U.S. This impacts us in 2 ways. First, lower tax rates in certain jurisdictions outside the U.S. are achieved only when we pass certain income thresholds. And second, lower pretax income diminishes our ability to utilize tax loss carry forwards and other tax credits. Another factor relates to discrete tax events, which we now anticipate will have a negative impact on the rate this year.
If pretax earnings continues at the current level, we would expect our ongoing tax rate to be in the low '30s in the midterm. As earnings increase about certain income threshold outside the U.S., we would expect the tax rate to be modestly below this range. Now these comments relate to the effective tax rate. The ultimate goal of our tax funding is to reduce the amount of taxes actually paid in any given year, and we measure this through the cash tax rate. 
Our cash tax rate has been in the upper 20% range for the past few years, and had been trending down modestly. We expect the tax -- the cash tax rate to again be in this upper 20% range and continue the downward trend in 2011 and for the midterm.
Now before getting into the segment, I want to comment on our free cash flow. In the first half of the year, our free cash flow was well below prior year levels due to lower operating results and higher working capital, as well as the timing of pension payments. 
Looking at the third quarter, our free cash flow came in at $189 million. This is in line with our expectations and well ahead of last year due to the significant progress we made in Q3 in returning to more typical working capital levels. 
Turning to Slide 8. Our pressure-sensitive materials segment delivered 2% organic sales growth, driven by pricing and partially offset by lower volume. PSM to volume in the third quarter was down approximately 2.5%, an improvement over the second quarter's 5% volume decline. This improvement in the trend reflects a moderation in label and packaging materials declines in Europe and an uptick in Asia-Pacific, which return to positive volume growth in the quarter. 
In addition to experiencing general softness in our markets, we also commented last quarter that we thought we lost some share in lower margin categories in Europe, well, we in fact did. While we do not yet have market or shared data for Q3, we believe that we may have regained a modest amount of the share in the quarter. 
And my last point on sales  in PSM relates to graphics and reflective solutions. Volumes in this business held up in Q2, but have now experienced the decline, due primarily to softness in Europe. Well remember that this businesses is more cyclical in nature than PSM's larger business, label and packaging materials. 
PSM's operating margin increased 50 basis points from prior year as the impact of lower volume was more than offset by lower employee-related costs. Our pricing and cost reduction actions have offset the inflation that we began to experience mid last year. The pricing on raw material cost now stabilizing, we feel that we've achieved a good position on the price cost front in PSM.
Retail branding and information solutions sales were down 7% on an organic basis in the third quarter. Lower sales were due to a continuation of the trend we saw in Q2 with a lower volume reflecting unit softness in the apparel market that Dean discussed earlier. As in the second quarter, the declines were most pronounced among mass-market retailers. RBIS margins were flat in the quarter as the negative impact of volume was offset by productivity and lower employee-related costs. Profits in consumer products came in as expected. The third quarter is typically a seasonally higher quarter for this business as it includes part of the back-to-school season, which starts in Q2. 
The operating margin in this business declined due primarily to the effect of lower volume and higher raw material costs, partially offset by lower advertising spend and employee related costs. We continue to expect margins for this business to be in the upper single digits for the full year.
And our other specialty converting businesses delivered modest sales growth in the quarter, driven by pricing from lower volume. Margins were down due to the lower volume partially offset by productivity initiatives. 
Moving on to the outlook for 2011. On Slide 11, we summarized the key factors that we expect to contribute to our P&L and cash flow in 2011. Slide 12 has our EPS and free cash flow guidance. I'll highlight just a few key assumptions that have changed from what we discussed last quarter. 
We now estimate organic sales growth in 2011 to be roughly flat. Reduction primarily reflects a change to our assumptions for the fourth quarter. With the increase our restructuring actions since last quarter and have accordingly increased our expectation of the cost to implement these actions. 
Annualized savings associated with 2011 restructuring actions are now expected to total approximately $55 million, with about 1/4 of the benefit to be realized this year. We continue to evaluate further opportunities to reduce costs, potentially including additional restructuring actions.
We've already discussed our increase in the expected tax rate for the year, that is the negative tax rate impact from our lower outlook for pretax income and other discrete events. And we made an additional $10 million pension contribution to the U.S. plan in the third quarter and we expect to contribute another $10 million in the fourth quarter. Full year pension contributions will approximate the level of last year.
Based on estimated sales and other assumptions, including the listed factors, we now expect adjusted earnings per share in 2011 of $2.15 to $2.30 and free cash flow of $215 million to $235 million. The low end of our EPS guidance assumes volume trends in Q4 that are consistent with what we experienced in Q3, and the high end reflects volume trends consistent with what we saw in September. Now, we'd be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: Well, so couple of things, as far as what is the amount of the discrete tax versus the effect of just lower pretax income to answer that part of the question first. It depends -- we said that the full year guidance is expected to be in the low to mid 30s, it depends where we ultimately settle out, but roughly about half of that is from the discrete items that we're flagging here. As far as what the discrete items are, they're specifically related to just as certain tax audits get finished out throughout the year, we anticipated that some of those -- complete more favorably than they actually ended up doing in foreign jurisdictions.

componenttextpreview: Well, my comments were, if income was to stay at the current levels, which means -- I'm not giving guidance, but if they were, we'd sustainably be at the low 30% range. As pretax income rises, we'd expect that the geographic mix and our ability to take ad
componenttext: Well, my comments were, if income was to stay at the current levels, which means -- I'm not giving guidance, but if they were, we'd sustainably be at the low 30% range. As pretax income rises, we'd expect that the geographic mix and our ability to take advantage of some of the lower tax jurisdictions would increase and therefore the tax rate would moderate somewhat from that level. Let's get back to the upper 20s that we had talked about before, so...

componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And in terms of the commentary on RBIS, that volume declines in Europe. Where do you think we are? I mean, did you see a similar volume decline in the second quarter, is it worse now, and is there any sort of parallel between what they're
componenttext: Okay, all right. And in terms of the commentary on RBIS, that volume declines in Europe. Where do you think we are? I mean, did you see a similar volume decline in the second quarter, is it worse now, and is there any sort of parallel between what they're seeing right now versus what the U.S. '08 and '09?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, for RBIS, it got sequentially a little bit worse. Q3 is normally not a strong quarter for us anyway, and I think that many retailers continue to delay orders waiting for some of those lower input costs to flow into pricing for garments tha
componenttext: Well, actually, for RBIS, it got sequentially a little bit worse. Q3 is normally not a strong quarter for us anyway, and I think that many retailers continue to delay orders waiting for some of those lower input costs to flow into pricing for garments that will be ordered now for the -- mainly the spring, and little bit of the summer season. And that's the orders we'll take in the fourth quarter. Actually, the U.S. has been marginally worse for us. Actually, quite a bit worse than Europe. Europe has been better, its downward trend has been a lot less. Part of that is because I believe we're taking some market share. Part of that is because many of the retailers and brand owners we serve in Europe -- that are based in Europe also have a global footprint. So they're not just focused on European retail sales. And finally, we just don't have as much impact from mass market. We just don't have that high share of mass market retailers in Europe as we do in the U.S. So all of those factors together, actually had made Europe appear to be okay. And so far, we haven't really seen a change in that trajectory.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttextpreview: For the full year, we expect to maintain a working capital productivity we had at the end of last year, and you saw in the first half, we had flipped from that level, and then we recovered a good amount of that in Q3. So you could expect it to recover to
componenttext: For the full year, we expect to maintain a working capital productivity we had at the end of last year, and you saw in the first half, we had flipped from that level, and then we recovered a good amount of that in Q3. So you could expect it to recover to the previous levels we had. And that's focused on operating working capital. One thing to point out is, we have talked about lower incentive-based compensation, so there will obviously be a fewer accruals this year. So that impacts working capital slow, Ghansham.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. It does look like raw material seem to have leveled off and in some cases are starting to come down, especially in the propylene and acrylic space side. In terms of the pricing that you've been getting to offset the raw m
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. It does look like raw material seem to have leveled off and in some cases are starting to come down, especially in the propylene and acrylic space side. In terms of the pricing that you've been getting to offset the raw materials, what is your belief in terms of your ability to hold the pricing or -- and or when might you have to start giving it back?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well it's a great question, John. First of all, I want to give our team, especially in our materials business full credit for doing a great job of managing in that inflationary environment. We basically have a been able to close the gap, and that required
componenttext: Well it's a great question, John. First of all, I want to give our team, especially in our materials business full credit for doing a great job of managing in that inflationary environment. We basically have a been able to close the gap, and that required a significant amount of work, during the quarter, or during the last 4 quarters. The inflationary environment I would characterize is stable. Some of the input costs have gone down, but still some of the specialty materials that we buy -- we haven't seen lot of relief on pricing. I would just characterize the market is roughly stable at this point. And right now, and certainly throughout the third quarter, there's been -- I would characterize the market as kind of stable from a pricing perspective, so we don't see necessarily anybody really driving for volume by trying to lower prices right now, and I think that's because input costs are still relatively high.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just with regard to pension, it sounds like you're making some incremental contributions. Can you give us an update -- I know that pensions are obviously -- would have taken a decent hit with where the discount rates are and how the
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just with regard to pension, it sounds like you're making some incremental contributions. Can you give us an update -- I know that pensions are obviously -- would have taken a decent hit with where the discount rates are and how the markets are looking. How should we be thinking about incremental pension expenses for 2012, if things kind of just stop right now?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still going through that evaluation given the change in discount rates. One of the things that we know is, regardless of what those assumptions are, that assets have taken a hit overall this year, and so that's one of the reasons for us to inc
componenttext: Well, we're still going through that evaluation given the change in discount rates. One of the things that we know is, regardless of what those assumptions are, that assets have taken a hit overall this year, and so that's one of the reasons for us to increase the amount of contributions. As you'll recall we froze, defined benefit plan in the U.S. at the end of last year, and since then we said we have a concerted effort over the next few years to get that much closer to fully-funded and start to shift the asset base to more conservative assets to take out some of the volatility going forward. As far as exactly what it looks like next year, there's still a lot of discussion about what the return on asset assumption should be, as well as the discount rates. So you would expect a modest headwind going into the next year, though.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttextpreview: About half of that, okay. And from a strategic standpoint, is the idea in the fourth quarter to run your pressure sensitive business at a relatively low operating rate in order to really work down your inventories, and then see what happens to the raw mat
componenttext: About half of that, okay. And from a strategic standpoint, is the idea in the fourth quarter to run your pressure sensitive business at a relatively low operating rate in order to really work down your inventories, and then see what happens to the raw material market?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeffrey, we've been -- the inventory levels in pressure sensitive are actually in pretty good shape right now. The real question mark we have about inventories has more to do about customer behavior. If market conditions are soft, a lot of label conv
componenttext: Yes, Jeffrey, we've been -- the inventory levels in pressure sensitive are actually in pretty good shape right now. The real question mark we have about inventories has more to do about customer behavior. If market conditions are soft, a lot of label converters will simply just take the last couple of weeks of the year off and run their inventories down. And if we trim our inventories too much, we'll have service problems when the year turns around. So I think we've got a pretty good handle on that, but in terms of us actually trying to manipulate raw material prices by changing our inventory levels, that's generally not the way we work. We work to demand forecast schedule with a flow manufacturing philosophy. So it's more related to lean operating principles than it is trying to do anything external like you're suggesting.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. I understand that the volumes are tough in office products, but from a competitive standpoint, have conditions stabilized or are they still getting tougher?
componenttext: Okay. I understand that the volumes are tough in office products, but from a competitive standpoint, have conditions stabilized or are they still getting tougher?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, they -- I'd say they've really stabilized. The last few quarters, our market shares remained the same. And the only thing that -- the only category that's launched here in the label business has been the private label share. So, it's been incredibly s
componenttext: No, they -- I'd say they've really stabilized. The last few quarters, our market shares remained the same. And the only thing that -- the only category that's launched here in the label business has been the private label share. So, it's been incredibly stable, actually for the last 9 months -- the last 3 quarters.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011

componenttext: So from your point of view, the office products hit some kind of low point in 2011, and you're more optimistic for '12?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we are, mainly because of a lot of the new product launches that we've been recently announcing. The Martha Stewart partnership with Staples is a significant one because it gets us into some new categories like home and home office. We have a line o
componenttext: Well, we are, mainly because of a lot of the new product launches that we've been recently announcing. The Martha Stewart partnership with Staples is a significant one because it gets us into some new categories like home and home office. We have a line of sticky notes with -- that use transparent films that consumers seem to like. And we have some new product areas -- new products in the area of business builders for small office, home office type categories. So as we -- we're staying very consistent with the strategy, investment in innovation for new products where we -- you said 2011 was going to be the trough year. And I don't want to give an outlook yet for 2012 because we haven't made the plan. There is obviously an impact of the overall economy, and that's the one factor I can't relate to, but we are going to see significant amount of new product sales in office and Consumer Products in the fourth quarter of this year. So it's a timely turn of events.

componenttext: Well, so definitely have some jurisdictions where they're above 34%, a couple of -- there's a mix bag out there, various jurisdictions, in the 34%, remember there is a few points of the discrete items that I talked about -- about certain tax audits from a few years ago, not settling out as we expected them to be, and so forth, and that's -- it often happens in the second half of the year. So, I wouldn't look at 34% as the ongoing rate, as we -- I mentioned that is more in the low 30s and that would be -- high -- we're in a lot of countries that we have a high amount of variation between the various tax rates, depending whatever the country is installed.

componenttext: Yes, region by region, it can be a step function change as you start to grow earnings across the entire company because there's different impacts going on the various regions, you're going to see it more of a slow sliding scale.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The inventory to sales ratio stayed at historical lows now for the past couple of years, actually. Well obviously it's slightly way up right at the financial crisis time. The biggest impact on us actually is unit volume. If you read the newspapers or the
componenttext: The inventory to sales ratio stayed at historical lows now for the past couple of years, actually. Well obviously it's slightly way up right at the financial crisis time. The biggest impact on us actually is unit volume. If you read the newspapers or the press reports about how apparel retailers are doing, most of them are actually saying they're getting some sales increases, but those are all denominated in dollars because clothes are anywhere from 10% to 20% higher priced right now because of input costs, unit volumes have definitely declined. Now that trend is likely to start to reverse as raw material costs have come way down. And frankly, right now, a lot of the apparel manufacturers are scrambling for volumes, so I expect that, again another round that input cost will go down. So we should see a gradual improvement as we move forward over the next couple of quarters.
